Text

﻿THE STORY OF [AN AFRICAN FARM A Novel]192-an african farm a novel .

BY [RALPH IRON]52-ralph iron .

IN TWO VOLUMES . VOL . I.

1883 . All Rights reserved .

" [We]3409-we must see the first images which the external world casts upon the dark mirror of [his]52-ralph iron mind ; or must hear the first words which awaken the sleeping powers of thought , and stand by [his]52-ralph iron earliest efforts , if [we]3409-we would understand the prejudices , the habits , and the passions that will rule [his]52-ralph iron life . [The entire man]3410-the entire man is , so to speak , to be found in the cradle of [the child]3411-the child . "[192-an african farm a novel]

ALEXIS DE [TOCQUEVILLE]1-tocqueville .

THE STORY OF [AN AFRICAN FARM]2-an african farm

PART I.

CHAPTER I. SHADOWS FROM [CHILD - LIFE]3-child - life .

[The Watch]4-the watch .

THE full African moon poured down its light from the blue sky into [the wide , lonely plain]193-the wide , lonely plain . The dry , sandy earth , with [its]194-its coating of stunted " karroo "[200-their] bushes a few inches high , [the low hills that skirted [the plain]196-the plain]195-the low hills that skirted the plain , the milk - bushes with their long finger - like leaves , all were touched by a weird and an almost oppressive beauty as they lay in the white light .

In one spot only was the solemn monotony of [the plain broken]197-the plain broken . Near the centre a small

solitary " kopje "[200-their] rose . [Alone]198-alone [it]199-it lay there , a heap of round ironstones piled one upon another , as over some giant 's grave . Here and there a few tufts of grass or small succulent plants had sprung up among [its]199-it stones , and on the very summit a clump of prickly - pears lifted [their]200-their thorny arms , and reflected , as from mirrors , the moonlight on their broad fleshy leaves . At the foot of [the " kopje "]3412-the " kopje "[212-her] lay [the homestead]201-the homestead . First , [the stone - walled " sheep kraals "[244-the watch] and [Kaffir huts]203-kaffir huts]202-the stone - walled " sheep kraals " and kaffir huts ; beyond them [the dwelling - house]204-the dwelling - house a square , red - brick building with thatched roof . Even on [its]204-the dwelling - house bare red walls , and the wooden ladder that led up to [the loft]205-the loft , the moonlight cast a kind of dreamy beauty , and quite etherealized the low brick wall that ran before [the house]206-the house , and which enclosed a bare patch of sand and two straggling sun - flowers . On the zinc roof of [the great open waggon - house]207-the great open waggon - house , on the roofs of [the outbuildings that jutted from [its]204-the dwelling - house side]208-the outbuildings that jutted from its side , the moonlight glinted with a quite peculiar brightness , till it seemed

that every rib in the metal was of burnished silver .

Sleep ruled everywhere , and [the homestead]201-the homestead was not less quiet than [the solitary plain]210-the solitary plain . In [the farm - house]211-the farm - house , on [[her]212-her great wooden bedstead]213-her great wooden bedstead , [Tant ' Sannie]53-tant ' sannie , [the Boer - woman]214-the boer - woman , rolled heavily in [her]212-her sleep . [She]212-her had gone to bed , as [she]212-her always did , in [her]212-her clothes , and the night was warm and [the room]215-the room close , and [she]212-her dreamed bad dreams . Not of the ghosts and devils that so haunted [her]212-her waking thoughts ; not of [[her]212-her second husband]216-her second husband , [the consumptive Englishman]217-the consumptive englishman , whose grave lay away beyond [the ostrich - camps]218-the ostrich - camps , nor of [her]212-her first , [the young Boer]219-the young boer ; but only of [the sheep 's trotters [she]212-her had eaten for supper that night]220-the sheep 's trotters she had eaten for supper that night . [She]212-her dreamed that one stuck fast in [her]212-her throat , and [she]212-her rolled [her]212-her huge form from side to side , and snorted horribly .

In [the next room]221-the next room , where [the maid]222-the maid had forgotten to close the shutter , the white moonlight fell in in a flood , and made it light as day .

There were two small beds against the wall . In one lay [a yellow - haired child , with a low forehead and a face of freckles]223-a yellow - haired child , with a low forehead and a face of freckles ; but the loving moonlight hid defects here as elsewhere , and showed only the innocent face of [a child]224-a child in [its]224-a child first sweet sleep .

[The figure in the companion bed]225-the figure in the companion bed belonged of right to the moonlight , for it was of quite elfin - like beauty . [The child]3411-the child had dropped [her]3411-the child cover on the floor , and the moonlight looked in at the naked little limbs . Presently [she]212-her opened [her]212-her eyes and looked at the moonlight that was bathing [her]212-her . " [Em]54-em ! "[244-the watch] [she]212-her called to [the sleeper in the other bed]227-the sleeper in the other bed ; but received no answer . Then [she]212-her drew the cover from the floor , turned [her]212-her pillow , and pulling the sheet over [her]212-her head , went to sleep again .

Only in one of [the outbuildings that jutted from [the waggon - house]229-the waggon - house]228-the outbuildings that jutted from the waggon - house there was some one who was not asleep . [The room]215-the room was dark ; door and

shutter were closed ; not a ray of light entered anywhere . [The German overseer , to whom [the room]215-the room belonged]231-the german overseer , to whom the room belonged , lay sleeping soundly on [his]231-the german overseer , to whom the room belonged bed in the corner , [his]231-the german overseer , to whom the room belonged great arms folded , and [his]231-the german overseer , to whom the room belonged bushy grey and black beard rising and falling on [his]231-the german overseer , to whom the room belonged breast . But one in [the room]215-the room was not asleep . Two large eyes looked about in the darkness , and two small hands were smoothing the patchwork quilt . [The boy]234-the boy , who slept on a box under the window , had just awakened from [his]234-the boy first sleep . [He]234-the boy drew the quilt up to [his]234-the boy chin , so that little peered above it but a great head of silky black curls and the two black eyes . [He]234-the boy stared about in the darkness . Nothing was visible , not even the outline of one worm - eaten rafter , nor of the deal table , on which lay the Bible from which [[his]234-the boy father]235-his father had read before [they]236-them went to bed . [No one]237-no one could tell where the tool - box was , and where the fire - place . There was something very impressive to [the child]3411-the child in the complete darkness .

At the head of [[his]234-the boy father]235-his father 's bed hung a great

silver hunting watch . It ticked loudly . [The boy]234-the boy listened to it , and began mechanically to count . [Tick]55-tick tick tick ! one , two , three , four ! [He]234-the boy lost count presently , and only listened . Tick tick tick tick !

[It]241-it never waited ; it went on inexorably ; and every time it ticked [a man]242-a man died ! [He]234-the boy raised [himself]234-the boy a little on [his]234-the boy elbow and listened . [He]234-the boy wished it would leave off .

How many times had it ticked since [he]234-the boy came to lie down ? A thousand times , a million times , perhaps . [He]234-the boy tried to count again , and sat up to listen better . " Dying , dying , dying ! "[244-the watch] said the watch ; " dying , dying , dying ! "[244-the watch] [He]234-the boy heard it distinctly . Where were [they]236-them going to , [all those people]243-all those people ? [He]234-the boy lay down quickly , and pulled the cover up over [his]234-the boy head : but presently the silky curls reappeared .

" Dying , dying , dying ! "[235-his father] said [the watch]244-the watch ; " dying , dying , dying ! "[244-the watch]

[He]234-the boy thought of the words [[his]234-the boy father]235-his father had read that evening " For wide is the gate , and broad is the way , that leadeth to destruction and many there be which go in thereat . "[235-his father]

" Many , [many , many]3413-many , many ! "[244-the watch] said [the watch]244-the watch .

" Because strait is the gate , and narrow is the way , that leadeth unto life , and [few there be that find it]3414-few there be that find it . "[56-god]

" Few , few , [few]3415-few ! "[3411-the child] said [the watch]244-the watch .

[The boy]234-the boy lay with [his]234-the boy eyes wide open . [He]234-the boy saw before [him]234-the boy a long stream of [people]249-people , [a great dark multitude]250-a great dark multitude , that moved in one direction ; then [they]236-them came to [the dark edge of [the world]252-the world]251-the dark edge of the world and went over . [He]234-the boy saw [them]236-them passing on before [him]234-the boy , and there was nothing that could stop [them]236-them . [He]234-the boy thought of how [that stream]253-that stream had rolled on through all the long ages of the past how [the old Greeks and Romans]254-the old greeks and romans had gone over ; the countless millions of [China]5-china and [India]6-india , [they]254-the old greeks and romans were

going over now . Since [he]234-the boy had come to bed , how many had gone !

And the watch said , " Eternity , eternity , eternity ! "[234-the boy] " Stop [them]236-them ! stop [them]236-them ! "[234-the boy] cried [the child]3411-the child . And all the while the watch kept ticking on ; just like [God]56-god 's will , that never changes or alters , [you]256-you may do what [you]256-you please . Great beads of perspiration stood on [the boy]234-the boy 's forehead . [He]234-the boy climbed out of bed and lay with [his]234-the boy face turned to the mud floor . " Oh , God , [God]56-god ! save [them]236-them ! "[234-the boy] [he]234-the boy cried in agony . " Only some , only a few ! Only for each moment [I]267-the two sunflowers that stood before the door , out - stared by the sun am praying here one ! "[267-the two sunflowers that stood before the door , out - stared by the sun] [He]234-the boy folded [his]234-the boy little hands upon [his]234-the boy head . " [God]56-god ! [God]56-god ! save [them]236-them ! "[268-the boer - woman , seen by daylight] [He]234-the boy grovelled on the floor .

Oh , the long , long ages of the past , in which [they]258-they had gone over ! Oh , the long , long future , in which [they]258-they would pass away ! Oh ,

[God]56-god ! the long , long , long eternity , which has no end !

[The child]3411-the child wept ; and crept closer to the ground .

[The Sacrifice]57-the sacrifice .

[THE farm]260-the farm by daylight was not as [the farm]260-the farm by moonlight . [The plain]196-the plain was a weary flat of loose red sand , sparsely covered by dry karroo - bushes , that cracked beneath the tread like tinder , and showed [the red earth]263-the red earth everywhere . Here and there a milk - bush lifted its pale - coloured rods , and in every direction the ants and beetles ran about in the blazing sand . The red walls of [the farm - house]211-the farm - house , [the zinc roofs of [the out - buildings]266-the out - buildings]265-the zinc roofs of the out - buildings , the stone walls of [the " kraals]3416-the " kraals , "[3411-the child] all reflected the fierce sunlight , till the eye ached and blenched . No tree or shrub was to be seen far or near . [The two sunflowers that stood

before the door , out - stared by the sun]267-the two sunflowers that stood before the door , out - stared by the sun , drooped [their]267-the two sunflowers that stood before the door , out - stared by the sun brazen faces to the sand ; and the little cicada - like insects cried aloud among the stones of the " kopje . "[3411-the child]

[The Boer - woman , seen by daylight]268-the boer - woman , seen by daylight , was even less lovely than , when , in bed , [she]268-the boer - woman , seen by daylight rolled and dreamed . [She]268-the boer - woman , seen by daylight sat on a chair in [the great front room]269-the great front room , with [her]268-the boer - woman , seen by daylight feet on a wooden stove , and wiped [her]268-the boer - woman , seen by daylight flat face with the corner of [her]268-the boer - woman , seen by daylight apron , and drank coffee , and in [Cape Dutch]58-cape dutch swore that the beloved weather was damned . Less lovely , too , by daylight was [[the dead Englishman]270-the dead englishman 's child]271-the dead englishman 's child , [[her]270-the dead englishman little step - daughter]272-her little step - daughter , upon whose freckles and low , wrinkled forehead the sunlight had no mercy . " [Lyndall]59-lyndall , "[275-the little one] [the child]3411-the child said to [[her]3411-the child little orphan cousin]274-her little orphan cousin , who sat with [her]3411-the child on the floor threading beads , " how is it [your]3411-the child beads never fall off [your]3411-the child needle ? "[275-the little one] " [I]60-waldo try , "[60-waldo] said [the little one]275-the little one gravely , moistening [her]275-the little one tiny finger . " That is why . "[60-waldo]

[The overseer , seen by daylight]276-the overseer , seen by daylight , was a huge German , wearing a shabby suit , and with a childish habit of rubbing [his]276-the overseer , seen by daylight hands and nodding [his]276-the overseer , seen by daylight head prodigiously when pleased at anything . [He]276-the overseer , seen by daylight stood out at the kraals in the blazing sun , explaining to [two Kaffer boys]277-two kaffer boys the approaching end of [the world]252-the world . [The boys]279-the boys , as [they]279-the boys cut the cakes of dung , winked at [each other]280-each other , and worked as slowly as [they]279-the boys possibly could ; but [the German]281-the german never saw it .

Away , beyond the " kopje , "[60-waldo] [Waldo]60-waldo [[his]60-waldo son]282-his son herded the ewes and [lambs a small and dusty herd powdered all over from head to foot with red sand]283-lambs a small and dusty herd powdered all over from head to foot with red sand , wearing a ragged coat and shoes of undressed leather , through whose holes the toes looked out . [His]60-waldo hat was too large , and had sunk down to [his]60-waldo eyes , concealing completely the silky black curls . It was [a curious small figure]284-a curious small figure . [[His]60-waldo flock]285-his flock gave [him]60-waldo little trouble . It was too hot for [them]279-the boys to move far ; [they]279-the boys gathered round [every little milk - bush]286-every little milk - bush , as though [they]279-the boys

hoped to find shade , and stood there motionless in clumps . [He]60-waldo [himself]60-waldo crept under a shelving rock that lay at [the foot of [the " kopje]3418-the " kopje]3417-the foot of the " kopje , "[60-waldo] stretched [himself]60-waldo on [his]60-waldo stomach , and waved [his]60-waldo dilapidated little shoes in the air .

Soon , from the blue bag where [he]60-waldo kept [his]60-waldo dinner , [he]60-waldo produced a fragment of slate , an arithmetic , and a pencil . Proceeding to put down a sum with solemn and earnest demeanour , [he]60-waldo began to add it up aloud : " Six and two is eight and four is twelve and two is fourteen and four is eighteen . "[60-waldo] Here [he]60-waldo paused . " And four is eighteen and four is eighteen . "[60-waldo] The last was very much drawled . Slowly the pencil slipped from [his]60-waldo fingers , and the slate followed it into [the sand]287-the sand . For a while [he]60-waldo lay motionless , then began muttering to [himself]60-waldo , folded [his]60-waldo little arms , laid [his]60-waldo head down upon them , and might have been asleep , but for the muttering sound that from time to time proceeded from [him]60-waldo . [A curious old ewe]288-a curious old ewe came to sniff at [him]60-waldo ; but it was

long before [he]60-waldo raised [his]60-waldo head . When [he]60-waldo did , [he]60-waldo looked at [the far - off hills]289-the far - off hills with [his]60-waldo heavy eyes .

" [Ye]3419-ye shall receive [ye]3419-ye shall receive shall , shall , shall , "[295-he] [he]60-waldo muttered .

[He]60-waldo sat up then . Slowly the dulness and heaviness melted from [his]60-waldo face ; it became radiant . Mid - day had come now , and the sun 's rays were poured down vertically ; the earth throbbed before the eye .

[The boy]234-the boy stood up quickly , and cleared a small space from the bushes which covered [it]291-it . Looking carefully , [he]234-the boy found twelve small stones of somewhat the same size ; kneeling down , [he]234-the boy arranged them carefully on the cleared space in a square pile , in shape like an altar . Then [he]234-the boy walked to the bag where [his]234-the boy dinner was kept ; in it was a mutton chop and a large slice of brown bread . [The boy]234-the boy took them out and turned the bread over in [his]234-the boy hand , deeply considering it . Finally [he]234-the boy threw it away and walked to the altar with the meat , and laid it down on

the stones . Close by in the red sand [he]234-the boy knelt down . Sure , never since the beginning of [the world]252-the world was there so ragged and so small [a priest]294-a priest . [He]60-waldo took off [his]60-waldo great hat and placed it solemnly on the ground , then closed [his]60-waldo eyes and folded [his]60-waldo hands . [He]60-waldo prayed aloud .

" Oh , [God]56-god , [[my]295-he Father]3420-my father , [I]295-he have made [Thee]3420-my father a sacrifice . [I]295-he have only twopence , so [I]295-he can not buy a lamb . If the lambs were [mine]295-he , [I]295-he would give [Thee]3420-my father one ; but now [I]295-he have only this meat ; it is [my]295-he dinner - meat . Please , [[my]295-he Father]3420-my father , send fire down from [heaven]3422-heaven to burn it . [Thou]3423-thou hast said , Whosoever shall say unto [this mountain]3424-this mountain , Be [thou]3423-thou cast into [the sea]3425-the sea , nothing doubting , it shall be done . [I]295-he ask for the sake of [Jesus Christ]61-jesus christ . Amen . "[295-he]

[He]295-he knelt down with [his]295-he face upon the ground , and [he]295-he folded [his]295-he hands upon [his]295-he curls . The fierce sun poured down its heat upon [his]295-he head and upon [his]295-he altar . When [he]295-he looked up [he]295-he knew what [he]295-he should see the glory of [God]56-god ! For fear [his]295-he very heart stood still , [his]295-he breath

came heavily ; [he]295-he was half suffocated . [He]295-he dared not look up . Then at last [he]295-he raised [himself]295-he . Above [him]295-he was the quiet blue sky , about [him]295-he [the red earth]263-the red earth ; there were the clumps of silent ewes and [his]295-he altar that was all .

[He]295-he looked up nothing broke the intense stillness of the blue overhead . [He]295-he looked round in astonishment , then [he]295-he bowed again , and this time longer than before . When [he]295-he raised [himself]295-he the second time all was unaltered . Only the sun had melted the fat of the little mutton chop , and it ran down upon the stones . Then , the third time [he]295-he bowed [himself]295-he . When at last [he]295-he looked up , some ants had come to the meat on the altar . [He]295-he stood up and drove [them]297-them away . Then [he]295-he put [his]295-he hat on [his]295-he hot curls , and sat in the shade . [He]295-he clasped [his]295-he hands about [his]295-he knees . [He]295-he sat to watch what would come to pass . The glory of [the Lord God Almighty]56-god ! [He]295-he knew [he]295-he should see it .

" [[My]305-the two girls dear]3426-my dear [God]56-god is trying [me]305-the two girls , "[305-the two girls] [he]295-he said ; and [he]295-he sat there through the fierce heat of the afternoon . Still [he]295-he watched and waited when the sun began to slope , and when it neared the horizon and [the sheep]298-the sheep began to cast long shadows across [the

karro karroo]7-the karro karroo

, [he]295-he still sat there . [He]295-he hoped when the first rays touched [the hills]299-the hills till the sun dipped behind [them]299-the hills and was gone . Then [he]295-he called [[his]295-he ewes]300-his ewes together , and broke down the altar , and threw the meat far , far away into [the field]301-the field .

[He]295-he walked [home]302-home behind [his]295-he flock . [His]295-he heart was heavy . [He]295-he reasoned so : " [God]56-god can not lie . [I]306-the yellow - haired em had faith . No fire came . [I]306-the yellow - haired em am like [Cain]62-cain [I]306-the yellow - haired em am not [His]62-cain . [He]56-god will not hear [my]306-the yellow - haired em prayer . [God]56-god hates [me]306-the yellow - haired em . "[306-the yellow - haired em] [The boy]234-the boy 's heart was heavy . When [he]234-the boy reached [the " kraal "[306-the yellow - haired em] gate]304-the " kraal " gate [the two girls]305-the two girls met [him]234-the boy .

" Come , "[307-the girls] said [the yellow - haired Em]306-the yellow - haired em , " let [us]3427-us play "[234-the boy] coop.í There is still time before it gets quite dark . [You]234-the boy , [Waldo]60-waldo , go and hide on the

" kopjeí ; [Lyndall]59-lyndall and [I]234-the boy will shut eyes here , and [we]3427-us will not look . "[234-the boy]

[The girls]307-the girls hid [their]307-the girls faces in the stone wall of the sheep - kraal , and [the boy]234-the boy clambered half way up the " kopje . "[234-the boy] [He]234-the boy crouched down between two stones and gave the call . Just then the milk - herd came walking out of the cow - kraal with two pails . [He]309-he was [an ill - looking Kaffir]310-an ill - looking kaffir . " Ah ! "[234-the boy] thought [the boy]234-the boy , " perhaps [he]309-he will die to - night , and go to hell ! [I]54-em must pray for [him]309-he , [I]54-em must pray ! "[54-em]

Then [he]234-the boy thought " Where am [I]54-em going to ? "[54-em] and [he]234-the boy prayed desperately .

" Ah ! this is not right at all , "[234-the boy] [little Em]54-em said , peeping between the stones , and finding [him]234-the boy in a very curious posture . " What are [you]234-the boy doing [Waldo]60-waldo ? It is not the play , [you]234-the boy know . [You]234-the boy should run out when [we]313-we come to the white stone . Ah , [you]234-the boy do not play nicely . "[234-the boy]

" [I]54-em [I]54-em will play nicely now , "[54-em] said [the boy]234-the boy ,

coming out and standing sheepishly before [them]313-we ; " [I]59-lyndall [I]59-lyndall only forgot ; [I]59-lyndall will play now . "[59-lyndall]

" [He]234-the boy has been to sleep , "[59-lyndall] said freckled [Em]54-em . " No , "[63-the confession] said beautiful little [Lyndall]59-lyndall , looking curiously at [him]234-the boy ; " [he]234-the boy has been crying . "[234-the boy] [She]59-lyndall never made a mistake .

[The Confession]63-the confession .

ONE night , two years after , [the boy]234-the boy sat alone on the " kopje . "[234-the boy] [He]234-the boy had crept softly from [[[his]234-the boy father]235-his father 's room]316-his father 's room and come [there]317-there . [He]234-the boy often did , because , when [he]234-the boy prayed or cried aloud , [[his]234-the boy father]235-his father might awake and hear [him]234-the boy ; and [none]319-none knew [his]234-the boy great sorrow , and [none]319-none knew [his]234-the boy grief , but [he]234-the boy [himself]234-the boy , and [he]234-the boy buried them deep in [his]234-the boy heart .

[He]234-the boy turned up the brim of [his]234-the boy great hat and looked at the moon , but most at the leaves of the prickly pear that grew just before [him]234-the boy . They glinted , and glinted , and glinted , just

like [his]234-the boy own heart cold , so hard , and very wicked . [His]234-the boy physical heart had pain also ; it seemed full of little bits of glass , that hurt . [He]234-the boy had sat [there]317-there for half an hour , and [he]234-the boy dared not go back to [the close house]322-the close house .

[He]234-the boy felt horribly lonely . There was not one thing so wicked as [he]234-the boy in all [the world]252-the world , and [he]234-the boy knew it . [He]234-the boy folded [his]234-the boy arms and began to cry not aloud ; [he]234-the boy sobbed without making any sound , and [his]234-the boy tears left scorched marks where they fell . [He]234-the boy could not pray ; [he]234-the boy had prayed night and day for so many months ; and to - night [he]234-the boy could not pray . When [he]234-the boy left off crying , [he]234-the boy held [his]234-the boy aching head with [his]234-the boy brown hands . If [one]324-one might have gone up to [him]234-the boy and touched [him]234-the boy kindly , poor , ugly little thing ! [I]0-i think [his]234-the boy heart was well nigh broken .

With [his]234-the boy swollen eyes [he]234-the boy sat there on a flat stone at the very top of the " kopje "[234-the boy] ; and the tree , with every one of its wicked leaves , blinked , and blinked , and blinked at [him]234-the boy .

Presently [he]234-the boy began to cry again , and then stopped [his]234-the boy crying to look at it . [He]234-the boy was quiet for a long while , then [he]234-the boy knelt up slowly and bent forward . There was a secret [he]234-the boy had carried in [his]234-the boy heart for a year . [He]234-the boy had not dared to look at it ; [he]234-the boy had not whispered it to [himself]234-the boy , but for a year [he]234-the boy had carried it . " [I]234-the boy hate [God]56-god ! "[234-the boy] [he]234-the boy said . The wind took the words and ran away with them , among the stones , and through the leaves of the prickly pear . [He]234-the boy thought it died away half down the " kopje . "[234-the boy] [He]234-the boy had told it now !

" [I]64-fate love [Jesus Christ]61-jesus christ , but [I]64-fate hate [God]56-god . "[64-fate] The wind carried away that sound as it had done the first . Then [he]234-the boy got up and buttoned [his]234-the boy old coat about [him]234-the boy . [He]234-the boy knew [he]234-the boy was certainly lost now ; [he]234-the boy did not care . If half [the world]252-the world were to be lost , why not [he]234-the boy too ? [He]234-the boy would not pray for mercy any more . Better so better to know certainly . It was ended now . Better so .

[He]234-the boy began scrambling down the sides of the " kopje "[334-they] to go [home]302-home . Better so ! But oh , the loneliness , the agonized pain ! for that night , and for nights on nights to come ! The anguish that sleeps all day on the heart like a heavy worm , and wakes up at night to feed ! There are some of [us]327-us who in after years say to [Fate]64-fate , " Now deal [us]327-us [your]64-fate hardest blow , give [us]327-us what [you]64-fate will ; but let [us]327-us never again suffer as [we]327-us suffered when [we]327-us were [children]3428-children . "[305-the two girls] The barb in the arrow of childhood 's suffering is this its intense loneliness , its intense agony .

CHAPTER II . PLANS AND [BUSHMAN - PAINTINGS]65-bushman - paintings .

AT last came the year of the great drought , the year of eighteen - sixty - two , [I]0-i think . From end to end of [the land the earth]328-the land the earth cried for water . [Man]329-man and beast turned [their]330-their eyes to the pitiless sky , that like the roof of some brazen oven arched overhead . On [the farm]260-the farm , day after day , month after month , the water in [the dams]332-the dams fell lower and lower ; the sheep died in [the fields]333-the fields ; the cattle , scarcely able to crawl , tottered as [they]334-they moved from spot to spot in search of food . Week after week , month after month , the sun looked down from the cloudless sky , till the karroo - bushes were leafless sticks , broken into the earth , and [the earth]335-the earth itself was naked and bare ;

and only the milk - bushes , like old hags , pointed [their]334-they shrivelled fingers heavenward , praying for the rain that never came .

It was on an afternoon of a long day in that thirsty summer , that on the side of the " kopje "[54-em] furthest from [the homestead]201-the homestead [the two girls]305-the two girls sat . [They]305-the two girls were somewhat grown since the days when [they]305-the two girls played hide - and - seek there , but [they]305-the two girls were [mere children]338-mere children still . [Their]305-the two girls dress was of dark coarse stuff ; [their]305-the two girls common blue pinafores reached to [their]305-the two girls ankles , and on [their]305-the two girls feet [they]305-the two girls wore home - made " vel - schoen . "[54-em] [They]305-the two girls sat under a shelving rock , on the surface of which were still visible some old Bushman paintings , their red and black pigments having been preserved through long years from wind and rain by the overhanging ledge ; grotesque oxen , elephants , rhinoceroses , and a one - horned beast , such as [no man]339-no man ever has seen or ever shall .

[The girls]307-the girls sat with [their]307-the girls backs to the paintings . In [their]305-the two girls laps were a few fern and ice - plant leaves , which by dint of much searching [they]305-the two girls had gathered under the rocks . [Em]54-em took off [her]54-em big brown kappje and began vigorously to fan [her]54-em red face with it ; but [[her]54-em companion]341-her companion bent low over the leaves in [her]54-em lap , and at last took up an ice - plant leaf and fastened it on to the front of [her]54-em blue pinafore with a pin . " Diamonds must look as these drops do , "[54-em] [she]54-em said , carefully bending over the leaf , and crushing one crystal drop with [her]54-em delicate little finger . " When [I]54-em , "[54-em] [she]54-em said , " am grown up , [I]341-her companion shall wear real diamonds , exactly like these in [my]341-her companion hair . "[341-her companion] [[Her]54-em companion]341-her companion opened [her]341-her companion eyes and wrinkled [her]341-her companion low forehead . " Where will [you]54-em find them , [Lyndall]59-lyndall ? The stones are only crystals that [we]3429-we picked up yesterday . [Old Otto]66-old otto says so . "[341-her companion]

" And [you]54-em think that [I]341-her companion am going to stay [here]3430-here always ? "[341-her companion]

The lip trembled scornfully . " Ah , no , "[341-her companion] said [[her]54-em companion]341-her companion . " [I]341-her companion suppose some day [we]3429-we shall go somewhere ; but now [we]3429-we are only twelve , and [we]3429-we can not marry till [we]3429-we are seventeen . Four years , five that is a long time to wait . And [we]3429-we might not have diamonds if [we]3429-we did marry . "[341-her companion] " And [you]54-em think that [I]345-the girl am going to stay [here]3430-here till then ? "[345-the girl]

" Well , where are [you]54-em going ? "[345-the girl] asked [[her]54-em companion]341-her companion .

[The girl]345-the girl crushed an ice - plant leaf between [her]345-the girl fingers .

" Tant ' [Sannie]53-tant ' sannie is [a miserable old woman]3432-a miserable old woman , "[345-the girl] [she]345-the girl said . " [[Your]54-em father]3433-your father married [her]53-tant ' sannie when [he]3433-your father was dying , because [he]3433-your father thought [she]53-tant ' sannie would take better care of [the farm]260-the farm , and of [us]347-us , than [an Englishwoman]3435-an englishwoman . [He]3433-your father said [we]347-us should be taught and sent to [school]3436-school . Now [she]346-she saves every[345-the girl]

farthing for [herself]346-she , buys [us]347-us not even one old book . [She]346-she does not ill - use [us]347-us why ? Because [she]346-she is afraid of [[your]348-your father]3433-your father 's ghost . Only this morning [she]346-she told [her]346-she Hottentot that [she]346-she would have beaten [you]348-your for breaking the plate , but that three nights ago [she]346-she heard a rustling and a grunting behind the pantry door , and knew it was [[your]348-your father]3433-your father coming to " spookí [her]346-she . [She]346-she is [a miserable old woman]3432-a miserable old woman , "[345-the girl] said [the girl]345-the girl , throwing the leaf from [her]345-the girl ; " but [I]345-the girl intend to go to [school]3436-school . "[345-the girl]

" And if [she]346-she wo n't let [you]345-the girl ? "[345-the girl] " [I]345-the girl shall make [her]346-she . "[345-the girl] " How ? "[3411-the child] [The child]3411-the child took not the slightest notice of the last question , and folded [her]3411-the child small arms across [her]3411-the child knees . " Why do [you]345-the girl want to go , [Lyndall]59-lyndall ? "[3411-the child] " There is nothing helps in [this world]3439-this world , "[345-the girl] said [the child]3411-the child slowly , " but to be very wise , and to know everything to be clever . "[59-lyndall]

" But [I]59-lyndall should not like to go to [school]3436-school ! "[59-lyndall] persisted the small freckled face . " And [you]345-the girl do not need to . [I]345-the girl must learn . "[345-the girl]

" [I]345-the girl do not want [your]345-the girl sheep , "[345-the girl] said [the girl]345-the girl slowly ; " [I]54-em want things of [my]54-em own . "[360-the other]

[The lady in [Tant ' Sannie 's bedroom]356-tant ' sannie 's bedroom]3443-the lady in tant ' sannie 's bedroom was a gorgeous creature from a fashion - sheet , which [the Boer - woman]214-the boer - woman , somewhere obtaining , had pasted up at the foot of [her]214-the boer - woman bed , to be profoundly admired by [the children]358-the children . " It would be very nice , "[361-his master] said [Em]54-em ; but it seemed a dream of quite too transcendent a glory ever to be realized . At this instant there appeared at the foot of the " kopje "[59-lyndall] two figures the one , a dog , white and sleek , one yellow ear hanging down over [his]359-his left eye ; [the other]360-the other , [[his]359-his master]361-his master , [a lad of fourteen]362-a lad of fourteen , and no other than [the boy]234-the boy [Waldo]60-waldo , grown into [a heavy , slouching youth of fourteen]364-a heavy , slouching youth of fourteen . [He]361-his master wore an aged jacket much too large for [him]361-his master , and rolled up at the wrists , and , as of old , a pair of dilapidated " vel - schoens "[361-his master] and a felt hat . " What have [you]361-his master been doing to - day ? "[361-his master] asked

" [He]67-bonaparte was [one man]3454-one man , [only one]3455-only one , "[54-em] said [[her]54-em little companion]373-her little companion slowly , " yet [all the people in [the world]252-the world]3456-all the people in the world feared [him]67-bonaparte . [He]67-bonaparte was not born great , [he]67-bonaparte was common as [we]3458-we are ; yet [he]67-bonaparte was [master of [the world]252-the world]3459-master of the world at last . Once [he]67-bonaparte was only [a little child]3461-a little child , then [he]67-bonaparte was [a lieutenant]3462-a lieutenant , then [he]67-bonaparte was [a general]3463-a general , then [he]67-bonaparte was [an emperor]3464-an emperor . When [he]67-bonaparte said a thing to [himself]67-bonaparte [he]67-bonaparte never forgot it . [He]67-bonaparte waited , and waited , and waited , and it came at last . "[59-lyndall] " [He]67-bonaparte must have been very happy , "[59-lyndall] said [Em]54-em .

" [I]374-they do not know , "[374-they] said [Lyndall]59-lyndall ; " but [he]67-bonaparte had what [he]67-bonaparte said [he]67-bonaparte would have , and that is better than being happy . [He]67-bonaparte was [[their]374-they master]3465-their master , and [all the people]3466-all the people were white with fear of [him]67-bonaparte . one and [they]374-they were many , and [they]374-they got [him]375-he down at last . [They]374-they were like the wild cats when [their]374-they teeth are fast in a great dog , like cowardly wild cats , " said [the child]3411-the child , "[54-em] [they]374-they would not let [him]375-he go . There were many ; [he]375-he was [only one]3455-only one . [He]375-he was [one man]3454-one man , and [they]374-they were many , and [they]374-they were terrified at [him]375-he . It was glorious ! " said [the child]3411-the child .[341-her companion]

" And what then ? "[341-her companion] said [Em]54-em . " Then [he]375-he was alone there in [that island]3469-that island with [men]3470-men to watch [him]375-he always , "[54-em] said [[her]54-em companion]341-her companion , slowly and quietly , " and in the long lonely nights [he]375-he used to lie awake and think of the things [he]375-he had done in the old days , and the things [he]375-he would do if [they]374-they let [him]375-he go again . In the day when [he]375-he walked near [the shore]3471-the shore it seemed to [him]375-he that [the sea]3425-the sea all around [him]375-he was a cold chain about [his]375-he body pressing [him]375-he to death . "[341-her companion] " And then ? "[54-em] said [Em]54-em , much interested .

" [He]375-he died there in [that island]3469-that island ; [he]375-he never got away . "[54-em] " It is rather a nice story , "[382-the little teller of the story] said [Em]54-em ; " but the end is sad . "[3411-the child] " It is a terrible , hateful ending , "[3411-the child] said [the little teller of the story]382-the little teller of the story , leaning forward on [her]382-the little teller of the story folded arms ; " and the worst is , it is true . [I]234-the boy have noticed , "[234-the boy] added [the child]3411-the child very deliberately , " that it is only the made - up stories that end nicely ; the true ones all end so . "[234-the boy] As [she]382-the little teller of the story spoke [the boy]234-the boy 's dark , heavy eyes rested on [her]382-the little teller of the story face . " [You]234-the boy have read it , have [you]234-the boy not ? "[345-the girl] [He]234-the boy nodded . " Yes ; but the brown history tells only what [he]375-he did , not what [he]375-he thought . "[345-the girl]

" It was in the brown history that [I]234-the boy read of [him]375-he , "[234-the boy] said [the girl]345-the girl ; " but [I]234-the boy know what [he]375-he thought . Books do not tell everything . "[234-the boy]

" No , "[361-his master] said [the boy]234-the boy , slowly drawing nearer to [her]345-the girl and sitting down at [her]345-the girl feet . " What [you]345-the girl want to know [they]3474-they never tell . "[361-his master]

Then [the children]358-the children fell into silence , till [Doss]70-doss , the dog , growing uneasy at its long continuance , sniffed at [one and the other]388-one and the other , and [[his]70-doss master]361-his master broke forth suddenly ,

" If [they]3474-they could talk , if [they]3474-they could tell [us]358-the children now ! "[361-his master] [he]361-his master said , moving [his]361-his master hand out over the surrounding objects " then [we]358-the children would know something . This "[361-his master] kopje , í if it could tell [us]358-the children how it came here ! The " Physical Geographyí says , "[361-his master] [he]361-his master went on most rapidly and confusedly , " that [what were dry lands]3475-what were dry lands now were once [lakes]3476-lakes ; and what [I]234-the boy think is this [these low hills]3477-these low hills were once [the shores of [a lake]3479-a lake]3478-the shores of a lake ; this "[234-the boy] kopje " is some of the stones that were at the bottom , rolled together by the water . But there is this how did the water come to make one heap here alone , in [the centre of [the plain]196-the plain]3480-the centre of the plain ? "[234-the boy] It was a ponderous question ; [no one]237-no one volunteered an answer . " When [I]234-the boy was small , "[234-the boy] said [the boy]234-the boy , " [I]392-i always looked at it and wondered , and [I]392-i thought [a great giant]3482-a great giant was buried under it .[392-i]

Now [I]0-i know the water must have done it ; but how ? It is very wonderful . Did one little stone come first , and stop the others as they rolled ? " said [the boy]234-the boy with earnestness , in a low voice , more as speaking to [himself]234-the boy than to [them]358-the children .[392-i]

" Oh , [Waldo]60-waldo , [God]56-god put the little "[392-i] kopjeí here , " said [Em]54-em with solemnity . "[392-i] But how did [He]392-i put it here ? " "[234-the boy] By wanting . " "[234-the boy] But how did the wanting bring it here ? " "[234-the boy] Because it did . " The last words were uttered with the air of one who produces a clinching argument . What effect it had on [the questioner]3484-the questioner was not evident , for [he]234-the boy made no reply , and turned away from [her]3484-the questioner . Drawing closer to [Lyndall]59-lyndall 's feet , [he]234-the boy said after a while , in a low voice ,[234-the boy]

" [Lyndall]59-lyndall , has it never seemed to [you]59-lyndall that the stones were talking with [you]59-lyndall ? Sometimes , "[234-the boy] [he]234-the boy added in a yet lower tone , " [I]234-the boy lie under there[234-the boy]

with [my]0-i sheep , and it seems that the stones are really speaking speaking of the old things , of the time when the strange fishes and animals lived that are turned into stone now , and [the lakes]393-the lakes were here ; and then of the time when [the little Bushmen]394-the little bushmen lived [here]3430-here , so small and so ugly , and used to sleep in [the wild dog holes]396-the wild dog holes , and in the " sloots , í and eat snakes , and shoot the bucks with [their]394-the little bushmen poisoned arrows . It was one of [them]394-the little bushmen , [one of these old wild Bushmen]3485-one of these old wild bushmen , that painted those , "[234-the boy] said [the boy]234-the boy , nodding toward the pictures " one who was different from the rest . [He]234-the boy did not know why , but [he]234-the boy wanted to make something beautiful [he]234-the boy wanted to make something , so [he]234-the boy made these . [He]234-the boy worked hard , very hard , to find the juice to make the paint ; and then [he]234-the boy found this place where the rocks hang over , and [he]234-the boy painted them . To [us]358-the children they are only strange things , that make [us]358-the children laugh ; but to [him]234-the boy they were very beautiful . "[400-the fellow]

[The children]358-the children had turned round and looked at the pictures . " [He]234-the boy used to kneel here naked , painting , painting , painting ; and [he]234-the boy wondered at the things [he]234-the boy made [himself]234-the boy , "[400-the fellow] said [the boy]234-the boy , rising and moving [his]234-the boy hand in deep excitement . " Now [the Boers]3486-the boers have shot [them]3487-them all , so that [we]358-the children never see a little yellow face peeping out among the stones ; and the wild bucks have gone , and those days , and [we]358-the children are here . But [we]358-the children will be gone soon , and only the stones will be on here , looking at everything like they look now . Of course [I]400-the fellow know , "[400-the fellow] [the fellow]400-the fellow added slowly , " that it is [I]54-em who am thinking , not [they]3488-they who are talking ; but it seems as though it were [them]3488-they . Has it never seemed to [you]234-the boy that things that do not live are talkig to [you]234-the boy , [Lyndall]59-lyndall ? "[54-em] " No , it never seems so to [me]406-me , "[406-me] [she]400-the fellow answered . The sun had dipped now below [the hills]299-the hills , and [the boy]234-the boy , suddenly remembering the ewes and lambs , started to [his]234-the boy feet .

" Let [us]3489-us also go to [the house]206-the house and see who has come , "[214-the boer - woman] said [Em]54-em , as [the boy]234-the boy shuffled away to rejoin [[his]234-the boy flock]285-his flock , while [Doss]70-doss ran at [his]70-doss heels , snapping at the ends of the torn trousers as they fluttered in the wind .

CHAPTER III . [I]0-i WAS [A STRANGER]405-a stranger , AND [YE]406-me TOOK [ME]0-i IN .

AS [the two girls]305-the two girls rounded the side of the " kopje , "[53-tant ' sannie] an unusual scene presented itself . [A large group]408-a large group was gathered at the back door of [the homestead]201-the homestead .

On the door - step stood [the Boer - woman]214-the boer - woman , a hand on each hip , [her]214-the boer - woman face red and fiery , [her]214-the boer - woman head nodding fiercely . At [her]214-the boer - woman feet sat [the yellow Hottentot maid]411-the yellow hottentot maid , [her]214-the boer - woman satellite , and around stood [the black Kaffir maids , with blankets twisted round [their]412-the black kaffir maids , with blankets twisted round their half - naked figures half - naked figures]412-the black kaffir maids , with blankets twisted round their half - naked figures . Two , who stamped mealies in a wooden block , held the great stampers in [their]305-the two girls hands , and stared stupidly at the object of attraction . It certainly was not to look at [the old German overseer ,

who stood in the centre of [the group]414-the group]413-the old german overseer , who stood in the centre of the group , that [they]414-the group had all gathered together . [His]413-the old german overseer , who stood in the centre of the group salt - and - pepper suit , grizzly black beard , and grey eyes were as familiar to every one on [the farm]260-the farm as [the red gables of [the homestead itself]417-the homestead itself]416-the red gables of the homestead itself ; but beside [him]413-the old german overseer , who stood in the centre of the group stood [the stranger]418-the stranger , and on [him]418-the stranger all eyes were fixed . [Ever]71-ever and anon [the new - comer]419-the new - comer cast a glance over [his]419-the new - comer pendulous red nose to the spot where [the Boer - woman]214-the boer - woman stood , and smiled faintly .

" [I]53-tant ' sannie 'm not [a child]224-a child , "[53-tant ' sannie] cried [the Boer - woman]214-the boer - woman , in low Cape Dutch , " and [I]214-the boer - woman was n't born yesterday . No , by [the Lord]3492-the lord , no ! [You]3492-the lord ca n't take [me]214-the boer - woman in ! [[My]214-the boer - woman mother]3493-my mother did n't wean [me]214-the boer - woman on Monday . One wink of [my]214-the boer - woman eye , and [I]214-the boer - woman see the whole thing . [I]214-the boer - woman 'll have [no tramps]3494-no tramps sleeping on [[my]214-the boer - woman farm]3495-my farm , "[214-the boer - woman] cried [Tant ' Sannie blowing]53-tant ' sannie . " No , by [the Devil]3496-the devil , no ! not though [he]372-the man had sixty - times - six red noses . "[53-tant ' sannie]

There [the German overseer]422-the german overseer mildly interposed that [the man]372-the man was not [a tramp]424-a tramp , but [a highly

respectable individual , whose horse had died by an accident three days before]425-a highly respectable individual , whose horse had died by an accident three days before .

" Do n't tell [me]53-tant ' sannie , "[53-tant ' sannie] cried [the Boer - woman]214-the boer - woman ; " [the man]372-the man is n't born that can take [me]418-the stranger in . If [he]372-the man 'd had money would n't [he]372-the man have bought a horse ? [Men who walk]3498-men who walk are [thieves]3499-thieves , [liars]3500-liars , [murderers]3501-murderers , [[Rome]22-rome 's priests]3502-rome 's priests , [seducers]3503-seducers ! [I]418-the stranger see [the Devil]3496-the devil in [his]372-the man nose ! "[418-the stranger] cried [Tant ' Sannie]53-tant ' sannie shaking [her]53-tant ' sannie fist at [him]425-a highly respectable individual , whose horse had died by an accident three days before ; " and to come walking into [the house of [this Boer 's child]3506-this boer 's child]3505-the house of this boer 's child , and shaking hands as though [he]372-the man came on horseback ! Oh , no , no ! "[281-the german]

[The stranger]418-the stranger took off [his]418-the stranger hat , a tall , battered chimney - pot , and disclosed a bald head , at the back of which was a little fringe of curled white hair ; and [he]418-the stranger bowed to [Tant ' Sannie]53-tant ' sannie . " What does [she]53-tant ' sannie remark , [[my]281-the german friend]3507-my friend ? "[281-the german] [he]418-the stranger inquired , turning [his]418-the stranger cross - wise looking eyes on [the old German]428-the old german . [The German]281-the german rubbed [his]281-the german old hands and hesitated .

" [Ah]3508-ah well [ah]3508-ah [the Dutch [you]418-the stranger know]3509-the dutch you know[418-the stranger]

do not like [people who walk in [this country]431-this country]430-people who walk in this country ah ! "[418-the stranger]

" [[My]53-tant ' sannie dear friend]3510-my dear friend , "[53-tant ' sannie] said [the stranger]418-the stranger , laying [his]418-the stranger hand on [the German]281-the german 's arm , " [I]281-the german should have bought [myself]281-the german [another horse]3511-another horse , but crossing , five days ago , a full river , [I]281-the german lost [my]281-the german purse a purse with five hundred pounds in it . [I]281-the german spent five days on [the bank of [the river]3513-the river]3512-the bank of the river trying to find it could n't . Paid [a Kaffir]3514-a kaffir nine pounds to go in and look for it at the risk of [his]3514-a kaffir life could n't find it . "[281-the german] [The German]73-the german would have translated this information , but [the Boer - woman]214-the boer - woman gave no ear . " No , no ; [he]3514-a kaffir goes to - night . See how [he]3514-a kaffir looks at [me]281-the german [a poor unprotected female]3515-a poor unprotected female ! If [he]3514-a kaffir wrongs [me]281-the german , who is to do [me]281-the german right ? "[281-the german] cried [Tant ' Sannie]53-tant ' sannie . " [I]418-the stranger think , "[418-the stranger] said [the German]281-the german in an undertone , " if [you]418-the stranger did n't look at [her]3515-a poor unprotected female quite so much it might be advisable . [She]3515-a poor unprotected female ah [she]3515-a poor unprotected female might imagine that [you]418-the stranger liked [her]3515-a poor unprotected female too well , in fact ah "[418-the stranger]

" Certainly , [[my]53-tant ' sannie dear friend]3510-my dear friend , certainly , "[53-tant ' sannie] said [the stranger]418-the stranger . " [I]281-the german shall not look at [her]3515-a poor unprotected female . "[281-the german] Saying this , [he]418-the stranger turned [his]418-the stranger nose full upon [a small Kaffir of two years old]437-a small kaffir of two years old . [That small naked Kaffir]438-that small naked kaffir became instantly so terrified that [he]438-that small naked kaffir fled to [[his]438-that small naked kaffir mother]439-his mother 's blanket for protection , howling horribly . Upon this [the new - comer]419-the new - comer fixed [his]419-the new - comer eyes pensively on the stamp - block , folding [his]419-the new - comer hands on the head of [his]419-the new - comer cane . [His]419-the new - comer boots were broken , but [he]419-the new - comer still had the cane of [a gentleman]441-a gentleman . " Yo vaggabonds se [Engelschman]74-engelschman ! "[281-the german] said [Tant ' Sannie]53-tant ' sannie , looking straight at [him]419-the new - comer . This was a near approach to [plain English]442-plain english ; but [the man]372-the man contemplated the block abstractedly , wholly unconscious that any antagonism was being displayed toward [him]372-the man . " [You]372-the man might not be [a Scotchman]3517-a scotchman , or anything of that kind , might [you]372-the man ? "[418-the stranger] suggested [the German]281-the german . " It is the English that [she]446-mother irish hates . "[418-the stranger]

" [[My]0-i dear friend]3510-my dear friend , "[0-i] said [the stranger]418-the stranger , " [I]281-the german am[281-the german]

Irish every inch of [me]0-i father Irish , [mother Irish]446-mother irish . [I]0-i 've not a drop of English blood in [my]0-i veins . "[281-the german]

" And [you]372-the man might not be married , might [you]372-the man ? "[418-the stranger] persisted [the German]281-the german . " If [you]372-the man had [a wife]3519-a wife and [children]3428-children , now ? [Dutch people]3521-dutch people do not like [those who are not married]3522-those who are not married . "[418-the stranger] " Ah , "[214-the boer - woman] said [the stranger]418-the stranger , looking tenderly at the block , " [I]214-the boer - woman have [a dear wife]3523-a dear wife and [three sweet little children]3524-three sweet little children [two lovely girls]3525-two lovely girls and [a noble boy]3526-a noble boy . "[214-the boer - woman] This information having been conveyed to [the Boer - woman]214-the boer - woman , [she]214-the boer - woman , after some further conversation , appeared slightly mollified ; but remained firm to [her]214-the boer - woman conviction that [the man]372-the man 's designs were evil . " For , [dear Lord]3527-dear lord ! "[214-the boer - woman] [she]214-the boer - woman cried ; " [all Englishmen]3528-all englishmen are ugly ; but was there ever such [a red - rag - nosed thing with broken boots and crooked eyes]3529-a red - rag - nosed thing with broken boots and crooked eyes before . Take [him]372-the man to [[your]281-the german room]3530-your room , "[281-the german] [she]214-the boer - woman cried to [the German]281-the german ; " but all the sin [he]372-the man does [I]281-the german lay at [your]281-the german door . "[281-the german]

[The German]281-the german having told [him]372-the man how matters were arranged , [the stranger]418-the stranger made a profound bow to [Tant ' Sannie]53-tant ' sannie and followed [[his]418-the stranger host]454-his host , who led the way to [[his]418-the stranger own little room]455-his own little room .

" [I]418-the stranger thought [she]457-his companion would come to [her]457-his companion better self soon , "[418-the stranger] [the German]281-the german said joyously . " [Tant ' Sannie]53-tant ' sannie is not wholly bad , far from it , far . "[418-the stranger] Then seeing [[his]418-the stranger companion]457-his companion cast a furtive glance at [him]418-the stranger , which [he]418-the stranger mistook for one of surprise , [he]418-the stranger added quickly , " Ah , yes , yes ; [we]3531-we are [all a primitive people]3532-all a primitive people [here]3430-here not very lofty . [We]3531-we deal not in titles . [Every one]3534-every one is [Tanta]75-tanta and Oom aunt and [uncle]3535-uncle . This may be [[my]418-the stranger room]3536-my room , "[418-the stranger] [he]418-the stranger said , opening the door . " It is rough , [the room]215-the room is rough ; not [a palace]3538-a palace not quite . But it may be better than [the fields]333-the fields , a little better , "[418-the stranger] [he]418-the stranger said , glancing round at [[his]418-the stranger companion]457-his companion . " Come in , come in . round with a pleased , half - nervous smile on [his]418-the stranger old face .

" [[My]358-the children friend]3507-my friend , [[my]358-the children dear friend]3510-my dear friend , "[358-the children] said [the stranger]418-the stranger , seizing [him]418-the stranger by the hand , " may [the Lord]3492-the lord bless [you]418-the stranger , [the Lord]3492-the lord bless and reward [you]418-the stranger [the God of [the fatherless]3547-the fatherless and [the stranger]418-the stranger]3546-the god of the fatherless and the stranger . But for [you]418-the stranger [I]307-the girls would this night have slept in [the fields]333-the fields , with the dews of heaven upon [my]307-the girls head . "[307-the girls]

Late that evening [Lyndall]59-lyndall came down to [the cabin]460-the cabin with [the German]73-the german 's rations . Through the tiny square window the light streamed forth , and without knocking [she]59-lyndall raised the latch and entered . There was a fire burning on the hearth , and it cast its ruddy glow over [the little dingy room]461-the little dingy room , with [its]461-the little dingy room worm - eaten rafters and mud floor , and broken white - washed walls . A curious little place , filled with all manner of articles . Next to the fire was a great tool - box ; beyond that the little bookshelf with [its]461-the little dingy room well - worn books ; beyond that , in the corner , a heap

of filled and empty grain - bags . From the rafters hung down straps , " reims , "[345-the girl] old boots , bits of harness , and a string of onions . The bed was in another corner , covered by a patchwork quilt of faded red lions , and divided from the rest of [the room]215-the room by a blue curtain , now drawn back . On the mantelshelf was an endless assortment of little bags and stones ; and on the wall hung a map of [South Germany]9-south germany , with a red line drawn through it to show where [the German]281-the german had wandered . [This place]464-this place was [the one [home]302-home [the girls]307-the girls had known for many a year]465-the one home the girls had known for many a year . [The house where [Tant ' Sannie]53-tant ' sannie lived and ruled]468-the house where tant ' sannie lived and ruled was [a place to sleep in , to eat in , not to be happy in]469-a place to sleep in , to eat in , not to be happy in . It was in vain [she]53-tant ' sannie told [them]307-the girls [they]307-the girls were grown too old to go [there]317-there ; every morning and evening found [them]307-the girls [there]317-there . Were there not too many golden memories hanging about [the old place]472-the old place for [them]307-the girls to leave [it]472-the old place ?

Long winter nights , when [they]307-the girls had sat round the fire and roasted potatoes , and asked riddles ,

and [the old man]473-the old man had told of [the little German village]474-the little german village , where , fifty years before , [a little German boy]475-a little german boy had played at snowballs , and had carried home the knitted stockings of [a little girl who afterward became [[Waldo]60-waldo 's mother]477-waldo 's mother]476-a little girl who afterward became waldo 's mother ; did [they]307-the girls not seem to see [the German peasant girls]478-the german peasant girls walking about with [their]478-the german peasant girls wooden shoes and yellow , braided hair , and [the little children]479-the little children eating [their]479-the little children suppers out of little wooden bowls when [the good mothers]480-the good mothers called [them]479-the little children in to have [their]479-the little children milk and potatoes ?

And were there not yet better times than these ? Moonlight nights , when [they]307-the girls romped about the door , with [the old man]473-the old man , yet more [a child]224-a child than any of [them]307-the girls , and laughed , till the old roof of [the waggon - house]229-the waggon - house rang .

Or , best of all , were there not warm , dark , starlight nights , when [they]307-the girls sat together on the door - step , holding [each other]280-each other 's hands , singing German hymns , [their]307-the girls voices rising clear in the still night air till [the German]281-the german would draw

away [his]281-the german hand suddenly to wipe quickly a tear [the children]358-the children must not see ? Would [they]307-the girls not sit looking up at the stars and talking of [them]487-them of the dear Southern Cross , red , fiery Mars , [Orion]76-orion , with [his]473-the old man belt , and [the Seven Mysterious Sisters]77-the seven mysterious sisters and fall to speculating over [them]487-them ? How old were [they]307-the girls ? Who dwelt in [them]307-the girls ? And [the old German]73-the german would say that perhaps [the souls [we]489-we loved]488-the souls we loved lived in [them]307-the girls ; there , in that little twinkling point was perhaps [the little girl whose stockings [he]473-the old man had carried [home]302-home]490-the little girl whose stockings he had carried home ; and [the children]358-the children would look up at it lovingly , and call it " [Old Otto]66-old otto 's star . "[345-the girl] Then [they]307-the girls would fall to deeper speculations of the times and seasons wherein the heavens shall be rolled together as a scroll , and the stars shall fall as a fig - tree casteth [her]493-her untimely figs , and there shall be time no longer ; " when [the Son of man]3550-the son of man shall come in [His]3550-the son of man glory , and [all [His]3550-the son of man holy angels]3551-all his holy angels with [Him]3550-the son of man . "[281-the german] In lower and lower tones [they]307-the girls would talk , till at last [they]307-the girls fell into whispers ; then [they]307-the girls would

wish good night softly , and walk [home]302-home hushed and quiet .

To - night , when [Lyndall]59-lyndall looked in , [Waldo]60-waldo sat before the fire watching a pot which simmered there , with [his]60-waldo slate and pencil in [his]60-waldo hand ; [[his]60-waldo father]235-his father sat at the table buried in the columns of a three - weeks - old newspaper ; and [the stranger]418-the stranger lay stretched on the bed in the corner , fast asleep , [his]418-the stranger mouth open , [his]418-the stranger great limbs stretched out loosely , betokening much weariness . [The girl]345-the girl put the rations down upon the table , snuffed the candle , and stood looking at [the figure on the bed]498-the figure on the bed . " [Old Otto]66-old otto , "[345-the girl] [she]345-the girl said presently , laying [her]345-the girl hand down on the newspaper , and causing [the old German]428-the old german to look up over [his]428-the old german glasses , " how long did [that man]3552-that man say [he]3552-that man had been walking ? "[281-the german]

" Since this morning , [poor fellow]3553-poor fellow ! [A gentleman not accustomed to walking horse]3554-a gentleman not accustomed to walking horse died [poor fellow]3553-poor fellow ! "[345-the girl] said [the German]281-the german , pushing out [his]281-the german lip and glancing commiseratingly over [his]281-the german

" And do [you]281-the german believe [him]3552-that man , [Uncle Otto]78-uncle otto ? "[345-the girl]

" Believe [him]3552-that man ? why of course [I]281-the german do . [He]3552-that man [himself]3552-that man told [me]281-the german the story three times distinctly . "[281-the german]

" If , "[281-the german] said [the girl]345-the girl slowly , " [he]3552-that man had walked for only one day [his]3552-that man boots would not have looked so ; and if "[281-the german]

" If ! "[281-the german] said [the German]281-the german starting up in [his]281-the german chair , irritated that [any one]504-any one should doubt such irrefragable evidence " if ! Why , [he]3552-that man told [me]281-the german [himself]3552-that man ! " [We]3557-we are not cooks not [French cooks]3558-french cooks , not quite ; but it 's drinkable , drinkable , [I]59-lyndall think ; better than nothing , [I]59-lyndall think , "[59-lyndall] [he]281-the german added , nodding [his]281-the german head

[my]473-the old man chicken ; [you]59-lyndall will wake [him]510-the figure . "[473-the old man]

[He]281-the german moved the candle so that [his]281-the german own head might intervene between it and [the sleeper]506-the sleeper 's face ; and , smoothing [his]281-the german newspaper , [he]281-the german adjusted [his]281-the german spectacles to read . [The child]3411-the child 's grey - black eyes rested on [the figure on the bed]498-the figure on the bed , then turned to [the German]281-the german , then rested on [the figure]510-the figure again .

" [I]473-the old man think [he]510-the figure is [a liar]3559-a liar . Good night , [Uncle Otto]78-uncle otto , "[473-the old man] [she]59-lyndall said slowly , turning to the door .

Long after [she]59-lyndall had gone [the German]281-the german folded [his]281-the german paper up methodically , and put it in [his]281-the german pocket .

[The stranger]418-the stranger had not awakened to partake of the soup , and [[his]281-the german son]282-his son had fallen asleep on the ground . Taking two white sheep - skins from

the heap of sacks in the corner , [the old man]473-the old man doubled them up , and lifting [the boy]234-the boy 's head gently from the slate on which it rested , placed the skins beneath it .

" [Poor lambie]3560-poor lambie , [poor lambie]3560-poor lambie ! "[473-the old man] [he]473-the old man said , tenderly patting the great rough head ; " tired is [he]234-the boy ! "[473-the old man] [He]473-the old man threw an overcoat across [the boy]234-the boy 's feet , and lifted the saucepan from the fire . There was no place where [the old man]473-the old man could comfortably lie down [himself]473-the old man , so [he]473-the old man resumed [his]473-the old man seat . Opening a much - worn Bible , [he]473-the old man began to read , and as [he]473-the old man read pleasant thoughts and visions thronged on [him]473-the old man . " [I]523-the friends at emmaus was [a stranger]405-a stranger , and [ye]473-the old man took [me]523-the friends at emmaus in , "[523-the friends at emmaus] [he]473-the old man read . [He]473-the old man turned again to the bed where [the sleeper]506-the sleeper lay . " [I]473-the old man was [a stranger]405-a stranger . "[473-the old man]

Very tenderly [the old man]473-the old man looked at [him]473-the old man . [He]473-the old man saw not the bloated body nor the evil face of [the man]372-the man ; but , as it were , under deep disguise

and fleshly concealment , the form that long years of dreaming had made very real to [him]473-the old man . " [Jesus]61-jesus christ , [lover]3564-lover , and is it given to [us]3565-us , weak and sinful , frail and erring , to serve [Thee]61-jesus christ , to take [Thee]61-jesus christ in ! "[234-the boy] [he]473-the old man said softly , as [he]473-the old man rose from [his]473-the old man seat . Full of joy , [he]473-the old man began to pace [the little room]521-the little room . Now and again as [he]473-the old man walked [he]473-the old man sang the lines of a German hymn , or muttered broken words of prayer . [The little room]521-the little room was full of light . It appeared to [the German]73-the german that [Christ]61-jesus christ was very near [him]61-jesus christ , and that at almost any moment the thin mist of earthly darkness that clouded [his]61-jesus christ human eyes might be withdrawn , and that made manifest of which [the friends at [Emmaus]10-emmaus]523-the friends at emmaus , beholding it , said , " It is [the Lord]3492-the lord ! "[234-the boy]

Again , and yet again , through the long hours of that night , as [the old man]473-the old man walked [he]473-the old man looked up to the roof of [[his]473-the old man little room]525-his little room , with [its]525-his little room blackened rafters , and yet saw them not . [His]473-the old man rough , bearded face was illuminated with a radiant gladness ; and the night was not shorter

to [the dreaming sleepers]526-the dreaming sleepers than to [him]473-the old man whose waking dreams brought heaven near .

So quickly the night fled , that [he]473-the old man looked up with surprise when at four o'clock the first grey streaks of summer dawn showed themselves through the little window . Then [the old man]473-the old man turned to rake together the few coals that lay under the ashes , and [[his]473-the old man son]282-his son , turning on the sheep - skins , muttered sleepily to know if it were time to rise . " Lie still , lie still ! [I]67-bonaparte would only make a fire , "[67-bonaparte] said [the old man]473-the old man . " Have [you]473-the old man been up all night ? "[281-the german] asked [the boy]234-the boy . " Yes ; but it has been short , very short . Sleep again , [[my]67-bonaparte chicken]3567-my chicken ; it is yet early . "[67-bonaparte] And [he]473-the old man went out to fetch more fuel .

CHAPTER IV . BLESSED IS [HE]473-the old man THAT BELIEVETH .

[BONAPARTE BLENKINS]67-bonaparte sat on the side of the bed . [He]67-bonaparte had wonderfully revived since the day before , held [his]67-bonaparte head high , talked in a full sonorous voice , and ate greedily of all the viands offered [him]67-bonaparte . At [his]67-bonaparte side was a basin of soup , from which [he]67-bonaparte took a deep draught now and again as [he]67-bonaparte watched the fingers of [the German]281-the german , who sat on the mud floor mending the bottom of a chair .

Presently [he]67-bonaparte looked out , where , in the afternoon sunshine , a few half - grown ostriches might be seen wandering listlessly about , and then [he]67-bonaparte looked in again at [the little white - washed room]532-the little white - washed room , and at [Lyndall]59-lyndall , who sat looking at a book near

the door . Then [he]67-bonaparte raised [his]67-bonaparte chin and tried to adjust an imaginary shirt - collar . Finding none , [he]67-bonaparte smoothed the little grey fringe at the back of [his]67-bonaparte head , and began ,

" [You]281-the german are [a student of history]3568-a student of history , [I]67-bonaparte perceive , [[my]67-bonaparte friend]3507-my friend , from the study of these volumes that lie scattered about [this apartment]3570-this apartment ; this fact has been made evident to [me]67-bonaparte . "[67-bonaparte] " Well a little perhaps it may be , "[281-the german] said [the German]281-the german meekly . " Being [a student of history]3568-a student of history then , "[79-napoleon bonaparte] said [Bonaparte]67-bonaparte , raising [himself]67-bonaparte loftily , " [you]281-the german will doubtless have heard of [my]79-napoleon bonaparte great , of [[my]79-napoleon bonaparte celebrated kinsman]3572-my celebrated kinsman , [Napoleon Bonaparte]79-napoleon bonaparte ? "[79-napoleon bonaparte] " Yes , yes , "[281-the german] said [the German]281-the german , looking up .

" [I]3573-sir , [sir]3573-sir , "[3573-sir] said [Bonaparte]79-napoleon bonaparte , " was born at this hour , on an April afternoon , three - and - fifty years ago . "[281-the german]

" [Napoleon an Irishman]80-napoleon an irishman ! "[67-bonaparte]

" Yes , "[67-bonaparte] said [Bonaparte]67-bonaparte , " on [the mother]3579-the mother 's side , and that is how [we]3580-we are related . mine]3586-a cousin of mine . [She]539-her was [a woman]540-a woman ! See [her]539-her at [one of [the court]542-the court]541-one of the court balls amber - satin daisies in [her]539-her hair . [The girl]345-the girl knit [her]345-the girl brows . " A little , slightly , better . "[67-bonaparte]

[The German]281-the german went out to pick up the battered chimney - pot which had fallen before the door . " [I]0-i am sorry [you]67-bonaparte got the fright .
