and effect , no order , but a blind chance sporting . It were almost a mercy to cut [his]242-a man throat , if indeed [he]242-a man does not do it for [himself]242-a man .

[We]1526-we , however , do not cut [our]1526-we throats . To do so would imply some desire and feeling , and [we]1526-we have no desire and no feeling ; [we]1526-we are only cold . [We]1526-we do not wish to live , and [we]1526-we do not wish to die . One day a snake curls itself round the waist of [a Kaffir woman]887-a kaffir woman . [We]1526-we take it in [our]1526-we hand , swing it round and round , and fling it on the ground dead . [Every one]3534-every one looks at [us]1526-we with eyes of admiration . [We]1526-we almost laugh . Is it bravery to risk that for which [we]1526-we care nothing ? In truth , nothing matters . [This dirty little world full of confusion , and the bit of blue stretched overhead for a sky]1588-this dirty little world full of confusion , and the bit of blue stretched overhead for a sky , is worthless .

Existence , if it is not a dream , is a great pot , and [the Fate who stirs it round]1589-the fate who stirs it round cares nothing what rises to the top and what goes down , and laughs when the bubbles burst . And [we]1526-we do not care . Let it boil about . Why should [we]1526-we

trouble [ourselves]1526-we ? Nevertheless the physical sensations are real . Hunger hurts , and thirst ; therefore [we]1526-we eat and drink . Inaction pains [us]1526-we ; therefore [we]1526-we work like [galley - slaves]1590-galley - slaves . [No one]237-no one demands it , but [we]1526-we set [ourselves]1526-we to build [a great dam in red sand beyond [the graves]1593-the graves]1592-a great dam in red sand beyond the graves . In the grey dawn before the sheep are let out [we]1526-we are working at it . All day , while [the young ostriches [we]1526-we tend]1594-the young ostriches we tend feed about [us]1526-we , [we]1526-we work on through the fiercest heat . [The people]1595-the people wonder what new spirit has seized [us]1526-we now . [They]1595-the people do not know [we]1526-we are working for [our]1526-we life . [We]1526-we bear the greatest stones , and feel a satisfaction when [we]1526-we stagger under them , and are hurt by a pang that shoots through [our]1526-we chest . While [we]1526-we eat [our]1526-we dinner [we]1526-we carry on baskets full of earth , as though [the devil]3496-the devil drove [us]1526-we . [The Kaffir servants]645-the kaffir servants have a story that at night [a witch]1598-a witch and [two white oxen]1599-two white oxen come to help [us]1526-we . No wall , [they]645-the kaffir servants say , could grow so quickly under [one man]3454-one man 's hands .

At night , alone in [[our]1526-we cabin]1601-our cabin , [we]1526-we sit no more brooding over the fire . What should [we]1526-we think

of now ? It is all emptiness . So [we]1526-we take the old arithmetic ; and the multiplication table , which with so much pains [we]1526-we learnt long ago and forgot directly , [we]1526-we learn now in a few hours , and never forget again . [We]1526-we take a strange satisfaction in working arithmetical problems . [We]1526-we pause in [[our]1526-we building]1602-our building to cover the stones with figures and calculations . [We]1526-we save money for a Latin Grammar and an Algebra , and carry them about in [our]1526-we pockets , poring over them as over [our]1526-we Bible of old . [We]1526-we have thought [we]1526-we were utterly stupid , incapable of remembering anything , of learning anything . Now [we]1526-we find that all is easy . Has a new soul crept into this old body , that even [our]1526-we intellectual faculties are changed ? [We]1526-we marvel ; not perceiving that what [a man]242-a man expends in prayer and ecstasy [he]242-a man can not have over for acquiring knowledge . [You]1604-you never shed a tear , or create a beautiful image , or quiver with emotion , but [you]1604-you pay for it at the other end of [your]1604-you nature . [You]1604-you have just

so much force : when the one channel runs over the other runs dry .

And [we]1526-we turn to [Nature]144-nature . All these years [we]1526-we have lived beside [her]1605-her , and [we]1526-we have never seen [her]1605-her ; and now [we]1526-we open [our]1526-we eyes and look at [her]1605-her . The rocks have been to [us]1526-we a blur of brown : [we]1526-we bend over them , and the disorganised masses dissolve into a many - coloured , many - shaped , carefully - arranged form of existence . Here masses of rainbow - tinted crystals , half- fused together ; there bands of smooth grey and red methodically overlying each other . This rock here is covered with a delicate silver tracery , in some mineral , resembling leaves and branches ; there on the flat stone , on which [we]1526-we so often have sat to weep and pray , [we]1526-we look down , and see [it]1606-it covered with the fossil footprints of great birds , and the beautiful skeleton of a fish . [We]1526-we have often tried to picture in [our]1526-we mind what the fossiled remains of creatures must be like , and all the while [we]1526-we sat on them .

[The flat plain]1607-the flat plain has been to [us]1526-we a reach of monotonous red . [We]1526-we look at [it]1607-the flat plain , and every handful of sand starts into life . [That wonderful black people]1608-that wonderful black people , the ants , [we]1526-we learn to know ; see [them]1608-that wonderful black people make war and peace , play and work , and build [[their]1608-that wonderful black people huge palaces]1609-their huge palaces . [That smaller people [we]1526-we make acquaintance with also who live in the flowers]1610-that smaller people we make acquaintance with also who live in the flowers . The bitto flower has been for [us]1526-we a mere blur of yellow ; [we]1526-we find its heart composed of a hundred perfect flowers , [the homes of [the tiny black people with red stripes , who move in and out in [that little yellow city]1613-that little yellow city]1612-the tiny black people with red stripes , who move in and out in that little yellow city]1611-the homes of the tiny black people with red stripes , who move in and out in that little yellow city . Every bluebell has [its inhabitant]1614-its inhabitant . Every day the karroo shows [us]1526-we a new wonder sleeping in its teeming breast . On [our]1526-we way back to work [we]1526-we pause and stand to see the ground spider make its trap , bury itself in the sand , and then wait for the falling in of its enemy . Farther on walks a horned beetle , and near [him]1615-him starts open the door of a spider , who peeps out carefully , and quickly pulls it down again . On a karroo - bush a green fly is laying [her]1616-her silver eggs . [We]1526-we

carry them [home]302-home , and see the shells pierced , the spotted grub come out , turn to a green fly , and go away . [We]1526-we are not satisfied with what [Nature]144-nature shows [us]1526-we , and [we]1526-we see something for [ourselves]1526-we . Under the white hen [we]1526-we put a dozen eggs , and break one daily , to see the white spot wax into the chicken . [We]1526-we are not excited or enthusiastic about it ; but [a man]242-a man must think of something if [he]242-a man is to live at all . So [we]1526-we plant seeds in rows on [our]1526-we dam - wall , and pull one up daily to see how it goes with them . [Allardeen]145-allardeen buried [her]145-allardeen wonderful stone , and [a golden palace]1619-a golden palace sprung up at [her]145-allardeen feet . [We]1526-we do far more . [We]1526-we put a brown seed in [the earth]335-the earth , and a living thing starts out before [our]1526-we eyes starts upward why , no more than [Allardeen]145-allardeen can [we]1526-we say starts upward , and does not desist till it is higher than [our]1526-we heads , sparkling with dew in the early morning , glittering with yellow blossoms , shaking brown seeds with little embryo souls on to the ground . [We]1526-we look at it solemnly , from the time it is two small

leaves peeping above the ground and a soft white root , till [we]1526-we have to raise [our]1526-we faces to look at it ; but [we]1526-we find no reason for that upward starting .

[We]1526-we look into dead ducks and lambs . In the evening [we]1526-we carry [them]1621-them [home]302-home , spread newspapers on the floor , and lie working with [them]1621-them till midnight . With a started feeling near akin to ecstasy [we]1526-we open the lump of flesh called a heart , and find little doors and strings inside . [We]1526-we feel them , and put the heart away ; but every now and then return to look , and to feel them again . Why [we]1526-we like them so [we]1526-we can hardly tell .

A gander drowns itself in [[our]1526-we dam]1623-our dam . [We]1526-we take it out , and open it on the bank , and kneel , looking at it . Above are the organs divided by delicate tissues ; below are the intestines , artistically curved in a spiral form , and each tier covered by a delicate network of blood - vessels , standing out red against the faint blue background . Each branch of the blood - vessels is

comprised of a trunk , bifurcating and rebifurcating into the most delicate , hair - like threads , symmetrically arranged . [We]1526-we are struck with its singular beauty . And , moreover and here [we]1526-we drop from [our]1526-we kneeling into a sitting posture this also [we]1526-we remark : of that same exact shape and outline is [our]1526-we thorn - tree seen against the sky in midwinter : of that shape also is delicate metallic tracery between [our]1526-we rocks ; in that exact path does [our]1526-we water flow when without a furrow [we]1526-we lead it from [the dam]3444-the dam ; so shaped are the antlers of the horned beetle . How are these things related that such deep union should exist between [them]1625-them all ? Is it chance ? Can it be ? Or , are they not all the fine branches of one trunk , whose sap flows through [us]1526-we all ? That would explain it . [We]1526-we nod over the gander 's inside .

This thing [we]1526-we call existence ; is it not a something which has its roots far down below in the dark , and its branches stretching far out

into the immensity above , which [we]1526-we among the branches can not see ? Not a chance jumble ; a living thing , a whole , a One .

[We]1526-we nod over the gander ; then start up suddenly , look into the blue sky , throw [the dead gander]1626-the dead gander and the refuse into the dam , and go to work again . And so , it comes to pass in time , that [the earth]335-the earth ceases for [us]1526-we to be a weltering chaos . [We]1526-we walk in [the great hall of [the universe]1629-the universe]1628-the great hall of the universe , [our]1526-we soul looking up and round reverentially . Nothing is despicable all is meaning - full ; nothing is small all is part of a whole , whose beginning and end [we]1526-we know not . The life that throbs in [us]1526-we is a pulsation from it . And so , it comes to pass at last , that whereas the sky was at first a small blue rag stretched out over [us]1526-we , and so low that [our]1526-we hands might touch it , pressing down on [us]1526-we , it raises itself into an immeasurable blue arch over [our]1526-we heads , and [we]1526-we begin to live again .

CHAPTER II . WALDO 'S STRANGER .

[WALDO]60-waldo lay on [his]60-waldo stomach on [the red sand]1397-the red sand . [The small ostriches [he]60-waldo herded]1631-the small ostriches he herded wandered about [him]60-waldo , pecking at the food [he]60-waldo had cut , or at pebbles and dry sticks . On [his]60-waldo right lay [the graves]1593-the graves ; to [his]60-waldo left [the dam]3444-the dam ; in [his]60-waldo hand was a large wooden post covered with carvings , at which [he]60-waldo worked . [Doss]70-doss lay before [him]60-waldo , basking in the winter sunshine , and now and again casting an expectant glance at the corner of [the nearest ostrich camp]1634-the nearest ostrich camp . The scrubby thorn - trees under which [they]1635-they lay yielded no shade , but none was needed in that glorious June weather , when in the hottest part of the afternoon the sun was but pleasantly warm ; and

[the boy]234-the boy carved on , not looking up , yet conscious of the brown serene earth about [him]234-the boy and the intensely blue sky above .

Presently , at the corner of [the camp]1637-the camp , [Em]54-em appeared , bearing a covered saucer in one hand and in the other a jug , with a cup in the top . [She]54-em was grown into [a premature little old woman]1638-a premature little old woman , ridiculously fat , and wearing long dresses . The jug and saucer [she]54-em put down on the ground before the dog and [[his]60-waldo master]361-his master and dropped down beside [them]1635-they [herself]54-em , panting and out of breath . " Oh , [Waldo]60-waldo ! as [I]54-em came up [the camps]3869-the camps [I]54-em met [some one on horseback]4107-some one on horseback ; and [I]54-em do believe it must be [the new man]4108-the new man . "[54-em] [The new man]4108-the new man was [an Englishman to whom [the Boer - woman]214-the boer - woman had hired half [the farm]260-the farm]1641-an englishman to whom the boer - woman had hired half the farm . " [Hum]146-hum ! "[4108-the new man] said [Waldo]60-waldo .

" [He]4108-the new man is quite young , "[60-waldo] said [Em]54-em , " and [he]4108-the new man has brown hair , and beard curling close to [his]4108-the new man face , and such dark blue eyes . And , [Waldo]60-waldo ,[1646-she]

[I]0-i was so ashamed ! [I]0-i was just looking back to see , [you]60-waldo know , and [he]4108-the new man happened just to be looking back too , and [we]1644-us looked right into [each other]280-each other 's faces ; and [he]4108-the new man got red , and [I]0-i got so red . "[418-the stranger]

" Yes , "[418-the stranger] said [Waldo]60-waldo . " [I]418-the stranger must go now . Perhaps [he]4108-the new man has brought [us]1644-us letters from the post from [Lyndall]59-lyndall . And [you]60-waldo know [he]4108-the new man will have to stay with [us]1644-us till [[his]4108-the new man house]4109-his house is built . [I]418-the stranger must get [[his]4108-the new man room]848-his room ready . Good - bye ! "[418-the stranger] [She]1646-she tripped off again , and [Waldo]60-waldo carved on at [his]60-waldo post . [Doss]70-doss lay with [his]70-doss nose close to the covered saucer , and smelt that [some one]3445-some one had made nice little fat cakes that afternoon . [Both]750-both were so intent on [their]750-both occupation , that not till a horse 's hoofs beat beside [them]750-both in the sand did [they]750-both look up to see [a rider drawing in [his]1649-a rider drawing in his steed steed]1649-a rider drawing in his steed .

[He]70-doss was certainly not [the stranger whom [Em]54-em had described]1650-the stranger whom em had described . [A dark , somewhat French - looking little man of eight - and - twenty , rather stout ,

with heavy , cloudy eyes and pointed moustaches]1651-a dark , somewhat french - looking little man of eight - and - twenty , rather stout , with heavy , cloudy eyes and pointed moustaches . [His]70-doss horse was [a fiery creature , well caparisoned]1652-a fiery creature , well caparisoned ; a highly - finished saddle - bag hung from the saddle ; [the man]372-the man 's hands were gloved , and [he]372-the man presented the appearance an appearance rare on [that farm of [a well - dressed gentleman]1655-a well - dressed gentleman]1654-that farm of a well - dressed gentleman .

In an uncommonly melodious voice [he]372-the man inquired whether [he]372-the man might be allowed to remain [there]317-there for an hour . [Waldo]60-waldo directed [him]372-the man to [the farm - house]211-the farm - house , but [the stranger]418-the stranger declined . [He]418-the stranger would merely rest under the trees , and give [his]418-the stranger horse water . [He]418-the stranger removed the saddle , and [Waldo]60-waldo led the animal away to [the dam]3444-the dam . When [he]372-the man returned , [the stranger]418-the stranger had settled [himself]418-the stranger under the trees , with [his]418-the stranger back against the saddle . [The boy]234-the boy offered [him]372-the man of the cakes . [He]372-the man declined , but took a draught from the jug ; and [Waldo]60-waldo lay down not far off , and fell to work again . It mattered nothing if cold eyes saw it . It was not [his]60-waldo sheep - shearing machine . With material loves , as with human , [we]1662-we go mad once , love out , and

have done . [We]1662-we never get up the true enthusiasm a second time . This was but a thing [he]60-waldo had made , laboured over , loved and liked nothing more .

[The stranger]418-the stranger forced [himself]418-the stranger lower down in the saddle and yawned . It was a drowsy afternoon , and [he]418-the stranger objected to travel in [these out - of - the - world parts]1664-these out - of - the - world parts . [He]418-the stranger liked better civilized life , where at every hour of the day [a man]242-a man may look for [his]242-a man glass of wine , and [his]242-a man easy - chair , and paper ; where at night [he]242-a man may lock [himself]242-a man into [[his]242-a man room]848-his room with [his]242-a man books and a bottle of brandy , and taste joys mental and physical . [The world]252-the world said of [him]418-the stranger the all - knowing , omnipotent world , whom [no locks]1668-no locks can bar , who has the cat - like propensity of seeing best in the dark [the world]252-the world said that better than the books [he]418-the stranger loved the brandy , and better than books or brandy , that which it had been better had [he]418-the stranger loved less . But for [the world]252-the world [he]418-the stranger cared nothing ; [he]418-the stranger smiled blandly in its teeth . All life is an aimless dream ; if wine

and philosophy and [women]1671-women keep the dream from becoming a nightmare , so much the better . It is all [they]1672-they are fit for , all [they]1672-they can be used for . There was another side to [his]418-the stranger life and thought , but of that [the world]252-the world knew nothing and said nothing , as the way of [the wise world]1458-the wise world is .

[The stranger]418-the stranger looked from beneath [his]418-the stranger sleepy eyelids at [the brown earth]1676-the brown earth that stretched away , beautiful in spite of itself in that June sunshine ; looked at the graves , [the gables of [the farm - house]211-the farm - house showing over the stone walls of [the camps]3869-the camps]1677-the gables of the farm - house showing over the stone walls of the camps , at [the clownish fellow]1680-the clownish fellow at [his]418-the stranger feet , and yawned . But [he]418-the stranger had drunk of [the hind]1681-the hind 's tea , and must say something . " [[[Your]418-the stranger father]3433-your father 's place]4112-your father 's place , [I]418-the stranger presume ? "[418-the stranger] [he]418-the stranger inquired sleepily . " No ; [I]234-the boy am only [a servant]4113-a servant . "[234-the boy] " [Dutch people]3521-dutch people ? "[234-the boy] " Yes . "[234-the boy] " And [you]418-the stranger like the life ? "[234-the boy] [The boy]234-the boy hesitated .

" On days like these . "[418-the stranger] " And why on these ? "[418-the stranger] [The boy]234-the boy waited . " [They]4115-they are very beautiful . "[418-the stranger] [The stranger]418-the stranger looked at [him]418-the stranger . It seemed that as [the fellow]400-the fellow 's dark eyes looked across [the brown earth]1676-the brown earth [they]1687-they kindled with an intense satisfaction ; then [they]1687-they looked back at the carving .

What had [that creature]1688-that creature , so coarse - clad and clownish , to do with the subtle joys of the weather ? [Himself]418-the stranger , white - handed and delicate , [he]418-the stranger might hear the music with shimmering sunshine and solitude play on the finely - strung chords of nature ; but [that fellow]1689-that fellow ! Was not the ear in that great body too gross for such delicate mutterings ?

Presently [he]418-the stranger said , " May [I]418-the stranger see what [you]418-the stranger work at ? "[418-the stranger]

[The fellow]400-the fellow handed [his]400-the fellow wooden post . It was by no means lovely . [The men]1452-the men and birds were almost grotesque in [their]1452-the men laboured resemblance

to nature , and bore signs of patient thought . [The stranger]418-the stranger turned the thing over on [his]418-the stranger knee .

" Where did [you]418-the stranger learn this work ? "[418-the stranger] " [I]418-the stranger taught [myself]418-the stranger . "[418-the stranger] " And these zigzag lines represent "[234-the boy] " [A mountain]4116-a mountain . "[418-the stranger] [The stranger]418-the stranger looked . " It has some meaning , has it not ? "[418-the stranger] [The boy]234-the boy muttered confusedly , " Only things . "[234-the boy] [The questioner]3484-the questioner looked down at [him]234-the boy the huge , unwieldy figure , in size [a man]242-a man 's , in right of [his]418-the stranger child - like features and curling hair [a child]224-a child 's ; and it hurt [him]234-the boy it attracted [him]234-the boy and it hurt [him]234-the boy . It was something between pity and sympathy . " How long have [you]418-the stranger worked at this ? "[234-the boy] " Nine months . "[418-the stranger]

From [his]418-the stranger pocket [the stranger]418-the stranger drew [his]418-the stranger pocket - book , and took something from it . [He]418-the stranger could

fasten the post to [his]418-the stranger horse in some way , and throw it away in the sand at safe distance .

" Will [you]418-the stranger take this for [your]418-the stranger carving ? "[418-the stranger] [The boy]234-the boy glanced at the five - pound note and shook [his]234-the boy head . " No ; [I]418-the stranger can not . "[418-the stranger] " [You]418-the stranger think it is worth more ? "[372-the man] asked [the stranger]418-the stranger with a little sneer . [He]418-the stranger pointed with [his]418-the stranger thumb to [a grave]1701-a grave . " No ; it is for [him]372-the man . "[418-the stranger] " And who is there ? "[418-the stranger] asked [the stranger]418-the stranger . " [[My]418-the stranger father]3420-my father . "[418-the stranger] [The man]372-the man silently returned the note to [his]372-the man pocket - book , and gave the carving to [the boy]234-the boy ; and , drawing [his]372-the man hat over [his]372-the man eyes , composed [himself]372-the man to sleep . Not being able to do so , after a while [he]372-the man glanced over [the fellow]400-the fellow 's shoulder to watch [him]372-the man work . [The boy]234-the boy carved letters into the back .

" If , "[418-the stranger] said [the stranger]418-the stranger , with [his]418-the stranger melodious voice , rich with a sweetness that never shewed

itself in the clouded eyes , " if for such a purpose , why write that upon it ? "[418-the stranger]

[The boy]234-the boy glanced round at [him]418-the stranger , but made no answer . [He]234-the boy had almost forgotten [his]418-the stranger presence . " [You]234-the boy surely believe , "[418-the stranger] said [the stranger]418-the stranger , " that some day , sooner or later , [these graves]4118-these graves will open , and [those Boer - uncles with [[their]4119-those boer - uncles with their wives walk about here in the red sand , with the very fleshly legs with which they went to sleep wives]4120-their wives walk about here in [the red sand]1397-the red sand , with the very fleshly legs with which [they]4119-those boer - uncles with their wives walk about here in the red sand , with the very fleshly legs with which they went to sleep went to sleep]4119-those boer - uncles with their wives walk about here in the red sand , with the very fleshly legs with which they went to sleep ? [You]234-the boy believe it , do [you]234-the boy not ? Then why say , "[418-the stranger] [He]1710-he sleeps forever?í [You]234-the boy believe [he]1710-he will stand up again ? " "[418-the stranger] Do [you]418-the stranger ? " asked [the boy]234-the boy , lifting for an instant [his]234-the boy heavy eyes to [the stranger]418-the stranger 's face . Half taken aback , [the stranger]418-the stranger laughed . It was as though a curious little tadpole which [he]418-the stranger held under [his]418-the stranger glass should suddenly lift its tail and begin to ask questions .[418-the stranger]

" [I]418-the stranger ? no . "[418-the stranger] [He]418-the stranger laughed [his]418-the stranger short thick laugh . " [I]418-the stranger am a man who believes nothing , hopes[418-the stranger]

nothing , fears nothing , feels nothing , trusts nothing . [I]0-i am beyond the pale of humanity ; no criterion of what [you]234-the boy should be who live here among [your]234-the boy birds and bushes . "[418-the stranger]

The next moment [the stranger]418-the stranger was surprised by a sudden movement on the part of [the fellow]400-the fellow , which brought [him]400-the fellow close to [the stranger]418-the stranger 's feet . Soon after [he]418-the stranger raised [his]418-the stranger carving and laid it across [the man]372-the man 's knee . " Yes , [I]418-the stranger will tell [you]418-the stranger , "[418-the stranger] [he]418-the stranger muttered ; " [I]418-the stranger will tell [you]418-the stranger all about it . "[418-the stranger]

[He]418-the stranger put [his]418-the stranger finger on [the grotesque little mannikin at the bottom]1715-the grotesque little mannikin at the bottom Ah ! [that man who believed nothing , hoped nothing]1716-that man who believed nothing , hoped nothing , felt nothing ; how [he]1716-that man who believed nothing , hoped nothing loved [him]1716-that man who believed nothing , hoped nothing ! , and , with eager finger [the fellow]400-the fellow moved upward , explaining over fantastic figures and [mountains]1718-mountains , to the crowning bird from whose wing dropped a feather . At the end [he]418-the stranger spoke with broken breath short words , like [one who utters things of mighty import]1719-one who utters things of mighty import .

[The stranger]418-the stranger watched more the face than the

carving ; and there was now and then a show of white teeth beneath the moustaches as [he]418-the stranger listened .

" [I]418-the stranger think , "[418-the stranger] [he]418-the stranger said blandly , when [the boy]234-the boy had done , " that [I]949-his friend partly understand [you]418-the stranger . It is something after this fashion , is it not ? "[949-his friend] [He]418-the stranger smiled . " In [certain valleys]4125-certain valleys there was [a hunter]4126-a hunter . "[0-i] [He]418-the stranger touched [the grotesque little figure at the bottom]1722-the grotesque little figure at the bottom . " Day by day [he]4126-a hunter went to hunt for wild - fowl in [the woods]4127-the woods ; and it chanced that once [he]4126-a hunter stood on [the shores of [a large lake]4129-a large lake]4128-the shores of a large lake . While [he]4126-a hunter stood waiting in the rushes for the coming of the birds , a great shadow fell on [him]4126-a hunter , and in [the water]1461-the water [he]4126-a hunter saw a reflection . [He]4126-a hunter looked up to the sky ; but the thing was gone . Then a burning desire came over [him]4126-a hunter to see once again that reflection in [the water]1461-the water , and all day [he]4126-a hunter watched and waited ; but night came and it had not returned . Then [he]4126-a hunter went [home]302-home with [his]4126-a hunter empty bag , moody and silent . [[His]4126-a hunter comrades]1192-his comrades came questioning about[1727-the hunter]

[him]418-the stranger to know the reason , but [he]418-the stranger answered [them]1723-them nothing ; [he]418-the stranger sat alone and brooded . Then [[his]418-the stranger friend]949-his friend came to [him]418-the stranger , and to [him]418-the stranger [he]949-his friend spoke .

" "[1727-the hunter] [I]0-i have seen to - day , í [he]0-i said , " that which [I]1727-the hunter never saw before a vast white bird , with silver wings outstretched , sailing in the everlasting blue . And now it is as though a great fire burnt within [my]1727-the hunter breast . It was but a sheen , a shimmer , a reflection in the water ; but now [I]1727-the hunter desire nothing more on [earth]653-earth than to hold [her.í]4135-her.í [[His]0-i friend]949-his friend laughed . "[1727-the hunter] It was but a beam playing on the water , or the shadow of [your]1725-your own head . To - morrow [you]1725-your will forget [her]1726-her , í [he]0-i said . But to - morrow , and to - morrow , and to - morrow [the hunter]1727-the hunter walked alone . [He]1727-the hunter sought in [the forest]1728-the forest and in [the woods]4127-the woods , by [the lakes]393-the lakes and among the rushes , but [he]1727-the hunter could not find [her]1726-her . [He]1727-the hunter shot no more wild fowl ; what were [they]1731-they to [him]1727-the hunter ? " What ails him?í said [[his]1727-the hunter comrades]1192-his comrades . "[1727-the hunter] [He]1727-the hunter is mad , í said [one]324-one .

" No ; but [he]1727-the hunter is worse , í said [another]4138-another ; "[1727-the hunter] [he]1727-the hunter would see that which none of [us]1733-us have seen , and make [himself]1727-the hunter a wonder.í " Come , let [us]1733-us forswear [[his]1727-the hunter company]4139-his company , í said all . So [the hunter]1727-the hunter walked alone . One night , as [he]1727-the hunter wandered in the shade , very heart - sore and weeping , [an old man]4141-an old man stood before [him]1727-the hunter , grander and taller than [the sons of [men]3470-men]4142-the sons of men . "[473-the old man] Who are you?í asked [the hunter]1727-the hunter . " [I]473-the old man am Wisdom , í answered [the old man]473-the old man ; "[473-the old man] but [some men]1735-some men call [me]0-i Knowledge . All [my]0-i life [I]0-i have grown in [these valleys]1736-these valleys ; but [no man]339-no man sees [me]0-i till [he]339-no man has sorrowed much . The eyes must be washed with tears that are to behold [me]0-i ; and , according as [a man]242-a man has suffered , [I]0-i speak.í And [the hunter]1727-the hunter cried " Oh , [[you]4141-an old man who have lived [here]3430-here]4145-you who have lived here so long , tell [me]0-i , what is that great wild bird [I]0-i have seen sailing in the blue ? [They]4145-you who have lived here would have [me]0-i believe [she]4147-her is a dream ; the shadow of [my]0-i own head.í[0-i]

[The old man]473-the old man smiled . " [Her]4147-her name is Truth . [He]4148-he who has once seen [her]4147-her never rests again . Till death [he]4148-he desires her.í And [the hunter]1727-the hunter cried "[1727-the hunter] Oh , tell [me]0-i where [I]0-i may find her.í But [the old man]473-the old man said , " [You]1727-the hunter have not suffered enough , í and went . Then [the hunter]1727-the hunter took from [his]0-i breast the shuttle of Imagination , and wound on it the thread of [his]0-i Wishes ; and all night [he]0-i sat and wove a net .[0-i]

In the morning [he]0-i spread the golden net upon the ground , and into it [he]0-i threw a few grains of credulity , which [[his]0-i father]235-his father had left [him]0-i , and which [he]0-i kept in [his]0-i breast pocket . They were like white puff - balls , and when [you]1743-you trod on them a brown dust flew out . Then [he]0-i sat by to see what would happen . [The first that came into the net]1744-the first that came into the net was a snow - white bird , with dove 's

eyes , and [he]0-i sang a beautiful song " [A human - God]4151-a human - god ! [a human - God]4151-a human - god ! [a human - God!í it]4153-a human - god!í it sang . The second that came was black and mystical , with dark , lovely eyes , that looked into the depths of [your]1743-you soul , and [he]0-i sang only this "[1595-the people] Immortality!í

And [the hunter]1727-the hunter took [them]1746-them both in [his]1727-the hunter arms , for [he]1727-the hunter said " [They]1746-them are surely of [the beautiful family of Truth.í]4154-the beautiful family of truth.í Then came another , green and gold , who sang in a shrill voice , like one crying in [the marketplace]4155-the marketplace , "[1727-the hunter] Reward after Death ! Reward after [Death!í]147-death!í And [he]0-i said " [You]1743-you are not so fair ; but [you]1743-you are fair too , í and [he]1727-the hunter took it . And [others]4156-others came , brightly coloured , singing pleasant songs , till all the grains were finished . And [the hunter]1727-the hunter gathered all [his]1727-the hunter birds together , and built a strong iron cage called [a new creed]4158-a new creed , and put all [his]1727-the hunter birds in [it]4158-a new creed .[1727-the hunter]

Then [the people]1595-the people came about dancing and singing . " Oh , happy hunter!í [they]1595-the people cried . "[1727-the hunter] Oh , [wonderful man]1748-wonderful man ! Oh , delightful birds ! Oh , lovely songs!í [No one]237-no one asked where the birds had come from , nor how [they]1750-they had been caught ; but [they]1595-the people danced and sang before [them]1750-they . And [the hunter]1727-the hunter too was glad , for [he]1727-the hunter said " Surely Truth is among [them]1595-the people . In time [she]4159-her will moult [her]4159-her feathers , and [I]1727-the hunter shall see [her]4159-her snow - white form.í But the time passed , and [the people]1595-the people sang and danced ; but [the hunter]1727-the hunter 's heart grew heavy . [He]1727-the hunter crept alone , as of old , to weep ; the terrible desire had awakened again in [his]1727-the hunter breast . One day , as [he]1727-the hunter sat alone weeping , it chanced that [Wisdom]148-wisdom met [him]1727-the hunter . [He]1727-the hunter told [the old man]473-the old man what [he]1727-the hunter had done . And [Wisdom]148-wisdom smiled sadly .[1727-the hunter]

" [Many men]4163-many men , í [he]148-wisdom said , "[1727-the hunter] have spread that net

for Truth ; but [they]1752-they have never found [her]1753-her . On the grains of credulity [she]1753-her will not feed ; in the net of wishes [her]1753-her feet can not be held ; in the air of [these valleys]1736-these valleys [she]1753-her will not breathe . The birds [you]1755-you have caught are of the brood of Lies . Lovely and beautiful , but still lies ; [Truth]149-truth knows them not.í

And [the hunter]1727-the hunter cried out in bitterness " And must [I]1727-the hunter then sit still , to be devoured of this great burning?í And [the old man]473-the old man said ,[1727-the hunter]

" Listen , and in that [you]1755-you have suffered much and wept much , [I]1735-some men will tell [you]1755-you what [I]1735-some men know . [[He]4165-he who sets out to search for Truth]4166-he who sets out to search for truth must leave [these valleys of superstition]4167-these valleys of superstition for ever , taking with [him]1727-the hunter not one shred that has belonged to [them]4167-these valleys of superstition . Alone [he]1727-the hunter must wander down into [the Land of Absolute Negation and Denial]4168-the land of absolute negation and denial ; [he]1727-the hunter must abide there ; [he]1727-the hunter must resist temptation ; when the light breaks [he]1727-the hunter must arise and follow it into [the country of dry sunshine]4169-the country of dry sunshine . [The mountains of[1735-some men]

stern reality]4170-the mountains of stern reality will rise before [him]1727-the hunter ; [he]1727-the hunter must climb them : beyond them lies Truth.í

" And [he]1727-the hunter will hold [her]1757-her fast ! [he]1727-the hunter will hold [her]1757-her in [his]1727-the hunter hands!í [the hunter]1727-the hunter cried . [Wisdom]148-wisdom shook [his]148-wisdom head . "[473-the old man] [He]1727-the hunter will never see [her]1757-her , never hold [her]1757-her . The time is not yet.í " Then there is no hope?í cried [the hunter]1727-the hunter .[1727-the hunter]

" There is this , í said [Wisdom]148-wisdom : "[1727-the hunter] [Some men]1735-some men have climbed on [those mountains]1759-those mountains ; circle above circle of bare rock [they]1735-some men have scaled ; and , wandering there , in [those high regions]1760-those high regions , [some]1386-some have chanced to pick up on the ground , one white , silver feather , dropped from the wing of Truth . And it shall come to pass , í said [the old man]473-the old man , raising [himself]473-the old man prophetically and pointing with [his]473-the old man finger to the sky , " it shall come to pass , that when enough of those silver feathers shall have been gathered by the hands of [men]3470-men , and shall have been woven into a cord , and the cord into a net , that in that[0-i]

net Truth may be captured . Nothing but Truth can hold Truth . í

[The hunter]1727-the hunter arose . " [I]0-i will go , í [he]0-i said . But [Wisdom]148-wisdom detained [him]0-i .[0-i]

" Mark [you]4174-you well who leaves [these valleys]1736-these valleys never returns to [them]1736-these valleys . Though [he]0-i should weep tears of blood seven days and nights upon the confines , [he]0-i can never put [his]0-i foot across them . Left they are left forever . Upon [the road which [you]4174-you would travel]4176-the road which you would travel there is no reward offered . Who goes , goes freely for the great love that is in [him]0-i . The work is [his]0-i reward.í[1771-the bird]

" [I]1727-the hunter go , í said [the hunter]1727-the hunter ; "[1727-the hunter] but upon [the mountains]1764-the mountains , tell [me]0-i , which path shall [I]0-i take?í " [I]0-i am [the child of The - Accumulated - Knowledge - of - Ages]4178-the child of the - accumulated - knowledge - of - ages , í said [the man]372-the man ; "[0-i] [I]0-i can walk only where [many men]4163-many men have trodden . On [these mountains]1766-these mountains few feet have passed ; [each man]1432-each man strikes out a path for [himself]1432-each man . [He]1432-each man goes at [his]1432-each man own peril : [my]0-i voice [he]1432-each man hears no more . [I]0-i may follow after [him]1432-each man , but can not go before him.í

Then [Knowledge]150-knowledge vanished . And [the hunter]1727-the hunter turned . [He]1727-the hunter went to [[his]1727-the hunter cage]1769-his cage , and with [his]1727-the hunter hands broke down the bars , and the jagged iron tore [his]1727-the hunter flesh . It is sometimes easier to build than to break . One by one [he]1727-the hunter took [his]1727-the hunter plumed birds and let them fly . But when [he]1727-the hunter came to [his]1727-the hunter dark - plumed bird [he]1727-the hunter held it , and looked into [its]1770-its beautiful eyes , and [the bird]1771-the bird uttered [its]1771-the bird low , deep cry " Immortality!í And [he]1727-the hunter said quickly , "[1595-the people] [I]0-i can not part with it . It is not heavy ; it eats no food . [I]0-i will hide it in [my]0-i breast ; [I]0-i will take it with me.í And [he]1727-the hunter buried it there and covered it over with [his]1727-the hunter cloak . But the thing [he]1727-the hunter had hidden grew heavier , heavier , heavier till it lay on [his]1727-the hunter breast like lead . [He]1727-the hunter could not move with it . Then again [he]1727-the hunter took it out and looked at it . " Oh , [my]1727-the hunter beautiful ! [my]1727-the hunter heart 's own!í [he]1727-the hunter cried , "[1727-the hunter] may [I]0-i not keep you?í

[He]0-i opened [his]1727-the hunter hands sadly .

" Go!í [he]1727-the hunter said . "[1595-the people] It may happen that in Truth 's song one note is like [yours]1772-yours ; but [I]0-i shall never hear it.í

Sadly [he]1727-the hunter opened [his]1727-the hunter hand , and the bird flew from [him]1727-the hunter forever . Then from [the shuttle of imagination]1773-the shuttle of imagination [he]1727-the hunter took the thread of [his]1727-the hunter wishes , and threw it on the ground ; and the empty shuttle [he]1727-the hunter put into [his]1727-the hunter breast , for the thread was made in [those valleys]1774-those valleys , but the shuttle came from [an unknown country]1775-an unknown country . [He]1727-the hunter turned to go , but now [the people]1595-the people came about [him]1727-the hunter , howling . " [Fool]4180-fool , hound , demented lunatic!í [they]1595-the people cried . "[4156-others] How dared [you]1727-the hunter break [your]1727-the hunter cage and let the birds fly?í [The hunter]1727-the hunter spoke ; but [they]1595-the people would not hear [him]1727-the hunter .

" Truth ! who is [she]4181-her ? Can [you]1727-the hunter eat [her]4181-her ? can [you]1727-the hunter drink [her]4181-her ? who has ever seen [her]4181-her ? [Your]1727-the hunter birds were real : all could hear [them]1595-the people sing ![4156-others]

Oh , [fool]4180-fool ! [vile reptile]1779-vile reptile ! atheist!í [they]1595-the people cried , " [you]1727-the hunter pollute the air.í[418-the stranger]

" Come , let [us]4182-us take up stones and stone [him]1727-the hunter , í cried [some]1386-some . "[418-the stranger] What affair is it of ours?í said [others]4156-others . " Let [the idiot]4184-the idiot go , í and went away . But [the rest]647-the rest gathered up stones and mud and threw at [him]1727-the hunter . At last , when [he]1727-the hunter was bruised and cut , [the hunter]1727-the hunter crept away into [the woods]4127-the woods . And it was evening about [him]1727-the hunter . "[1789-they] At every word [the stranger]418-the stranger spoke [the fellow]400-the fellow 's eyes flashed back on [him]418-the stranger yes , and yes , and yes ! [The stranger]418-the stranger smiled . It was almost worth the trouble of exerting [oneself]1784-oneself , even on a lazy afternoon , to win those passionate flashes , more thirsty and desiring than the love - glances of [a woman]540-a woman .

" [He]418-the stranger wandered on and on , "[1791-we] said [the stranger]418-the stranger , " and the shade grew deeper . [He]418-the stranger was on the borders now of [the land where it is always night]4188-the land where it is always night . Then [he]418-the stranger stepped into it , and there was no light there . With [his]418-the stranger hands [he]418-the stranger groped ;[1789-they]

but each branch as [he]418-the stranger touched it broke off , and the earth was covered with cinders . At every step [his]418-the stranger foot sank in , and a fine cloud of impalpable ashes flew up into [his]418-the stranger face ; and it was dark . So [he]418-the stranger sat down upon a stone and buried [his]418-the stranger face in [his]418-the stranger hands , to wait in [the Land of Negation]1787-the land of negation and [Denial]151-denial till the light came .

And it was night in [his]418-the stranger heart also .

Then from [the marshes]1788-the marshes to [his]418-the stranger right and left cold mists arose and closed about [him]418-the stranger . A fine , imperceptible rain fell in the dark , and great drops gathered on [his]418-the stranger hair and clothes . [His]418-the stranger heart beat slowly , and a numbness crept through all [his]418-the stranger limbs . Then , looking up , two merry wisp lights came dancing . [He]418-the stranger lifted [his]418-the stranger head to look at [them]1789-they . Nearer , nearer [they]1789-they came . So warm , so bright , they danced like stars of fire . [They]1789-they stood before [him]418-the stranger at last . From the centre of the radiating flame in one looked out [a woman]540-a woman 's face , laughing , dimpled , with streaming yellow hair . In the centre of the other were merry

laughing ripples , like the bubbles on a glass of wine . [They]1789-they danced before [him]418-the stranger .

" Who are [you]1789-they , í asked [the hunter]1727-the hunter , "[1789-they] who alone come to [me]0-i in [my]0-i solitude and darkness?í " [We]1791-we are [the twins Sensuality]4190-the twins sensuality , í [they]1789-they cried . "[0-i] [[Our]1791-we father]4033-our father 's name is Human - Nature , and [[our]1791-we mother]1793-our mother 's name is [Excess]152-excess . [We]1791-we are as old as [the hills]299-the hills and [rivers]1795-rivers , as old as [the first man]1796-the first man ; but [we]1791-we never die , í [they]1789-they laughed . " Oh , let [me]1799-his wrap [my]1799-his arms about [you!í]153-you!í cried [the first]4191-the first ; "[1799-his] they are soft and warm . [Your]1797-your heart is frozen now , but [I]0-i will make it beat . Oh , come to me!í " [I]1789-they will pour [my]1789-they hot life into [you]1797-your , í said [the second]4192-the second ; "[1789-they] [your]1797-your brain is numb , and [your]1797-your limbs are dead now ; but [they]1789-they shall live with a fierce free life . Oh , let [me]0-i pour it in!í

" Oh , follow [us]1791-we , í [they]1791-we cried , "[234-the boy] and live with [us]1791-we . Nobler hearts than [yours]1797-your have sat here in this darkness to wait , and [they]1789-they have come to [us]1791-we and [we]1791-we to [them]1789-they ; and [they]1789-they have never left

[us]1791-we , never . All else is a delusion , but [we]1791-we are real , [we]1791-we are real . Truth is a shadow ; the valleys of superstition are a farce : [the earth]335-the earth is of ashes , the trees all rotten ; but [we]1791-we feel [us]1791-we [we]1791-we live ! [You]1797-your can not doubt [us]1791-we . Feel [us]1791-we how warm [we]1791-we are ! Oh , come to [us]1791-we ! Oh , live with us!í

Nearer and nearer round [his]1799-his head [they]1789-they hovered , and the cold drops melted on [his]1799-his forehead . The bright light shot into [his]1799-his eyes , dazzling [him]1799-his , and the frozen blood began to run . And [he]1799-his said " Yes , why should [I]0-i die here in this awful darkness ? They are warm , they are warm!í and [he]1799-his stretched out [his]1799-his hands to take them . Then in a moment there arose before [him]1799-his the image of the thing [he]1799-his had loved , and [his]1799-his hand dropped to [his]1799-his side . "[0-i] Oh , come to us!í [they]1789-they cried . But [he]1799-his buried [his]1799-his face .

" [You]1789-they dazzle [my]1727-the hunter eyes , í [he]1799-his cried , "[1727-the hunter] [you]1789-they make [my]0-i heart warm ; but [you]1789-they can not give [me]0-i what

[I]0-i desire . [I]0-i will wait here wait till [I]0-i die ; but [I]0-i will not follow [you]1789-they . Go!í

[He]1799-his covered [his]1799-his face with [his]1799-his hands and would not listen ; and when [he]1799-his looked up again [they]1800-they were two twinkling stars , that vanished in the distance . And the long , long night rolled on . All who leave [the valley of superstition]1801-the valley of superstition pass through [that dark land]1802-that dark land ; but [some]1386-some go through [it]1802-that dark land in a few days , [some linger there]1804-some linger there for months , some for years , and [some]1386-some die there . At last for [the hunter]1727-the hunter a faint light played along the horizon , and [he]1727-the hunter rose to follow it.í [The boy]234-the boy had crept closer ; [his]234-the boy hot breath almost touched [the stranger]418-the stranger 's hand ; a mystic wonder filled [his]234-the boy eyes .

" [He]1727-the hunter reached that light at last , and stepped into the broad sunshine , í said [the stranger]418-the stranger . "[1727-the hunter] Then before [him]1727-the hunter rose [the almighty mountains of [Dry - facts]34-dry - facts and [Realities]35-realities]1809-the almighty mountains of dry - facts and realities . The clear sunshine played on them , and the tops were lost in

the clouds . At the foot [many paths]1810-many paths ran up . An exultant cry burst from [the hunter]1727-the hunter . [He]1727-the hunter chose the straightest and began to climb ; and the rocks and ridges resounded with [his]1727-the hunter song . [They]1812-they had exaggerated ; after all , it was not so high , nor was the road so steep ! A few days , a few weeks , a few months at most , and then the top ! Not one feather only would [he]1727-the hunter pick up ; [he]1727-the hunter would gather all that [other men]1813-other men had found weave the net capture Truth hold [her]1814-her fast touch [her]1814-her with [his]1727-the hunter hands clasp [her]1814-her !

[He]1727-the hunter laughed in the merry sunshine , and sang loud . Victory was very near . Nevertheless , after a while [the path]885-the path grew steeper . [He]1727-the hunter needed all [his]1727-the hunter breath for climbing , and the singing died away . On the right and left rose huge rocks , devoid of lichen or moss , and in the lava - like earth chasms yawned . Here and there [he]1727-the hunter saw a sheen of white bones . Now too [the path]885-the path began to grow less and

less marked ; then it became a mere trace , with a footmark here and there ; then it ceased altogether . [He]1727-the hunter sang no more , but struck forth a path for [himself]1727-the hunter , until it reached a mighty wall of rock , smooth and without break , stretching as far as the eye could see . " [I]1823-they will rear a stair against it ; and , once this wall climbed , [I]1823-they shall be almost there , í [he]1823-they said bravely ; and set to work . With [his]1727-the hunter shuttle of imagination [he]1727-the hunter dug out stones ; but half of them would not fit , and sometimes half a month 's work would roll down because those below were ill chosen . But [the hunter]1727-the hunter worked on , saying always to [himself]1727-the hunter , "[1823-they] Once this wall climbed , [I]0-i shall be almost there . This great work ended!í

At last [he]1727-the hunter came out upon the top , and [he]1727-the hunter looked about [him]1727-the hunter . Far below rolled the white mist over [the valleys of superstition]1817-the valleys of superstition , and above towered [the mountains]1764-the mountains . They had seemed low before ; [they]1764-the mountains were of an immeasurable height now , from crown to foundation surrounded by

walls of rock , that rose tier above tier in mighty circles . Upon them played the eternal sunshine . [He]1727-the hunter uttered a wild cry . When [he]1727-the hunter rose from the earth on which [he]1727-the hunter had fallen , [his]1727-the hunter face was white . In absolute silence [he]1727-the hunter walked on . [He]1727-the hunter was very silent now . In [those high regions]1760-those high regions the rarefied air is hard to breathe by those born in [the valleys]1820-the valleys ; every breath [he]1727-the hunter drew hurt [him]1727-the hunter , and the blood oozed out from the tips of [his]1727-the hunter fingers . Before [the next wall of rock]1821-the next wall of rock [he]1727-the hunter began to work . The height of this seemed infinite , and [he]1727-the hunter said nothing . The sound of [his]1727-the hunter tool rang night and day upon the iron rocks into which [he]1727-the hunter cut steps . Times and times , and again times , passed over [him]1727-the hunter , yet [he]1727-the hunter worked on ; but the wall towered up above [him]1727-the hunter to [heaven]3422-heaven . Sometimes [he]1727-the hunter prayed that a little moss or lichen might spring up on those bare walls to be a companion to [him]1727-the hunter ; but it never came .

And the years rolled on ; [he]1727-the hunter counted them

by the steps [he]1727-the hunter had cut a few for a year only a few . [He]1727-the hunter sang no more ; [he]1727-the hunter said no more , " [I]1727-the hunter will do this , or thatí [he]1727-the hunter only worked . And at night , when the twilight settled down , there looked out at [him]1727-the hunter from the holes and crevices in the rocks strange wild faces .[1727-the hunter]

" Stop [your]1727-the hunter work , [[you]1727-the hunter lonely man]4195-you lonely man , and speak to [us]1823-they , í [they]1823-they cried . "[1827-they] [My]0-i salvation is in work . If [I]0-i should stop but for one moment [you]1823-they would creep down upon [me]0-i , í [he]0-i replied . And [they]1823-they put out [their]1823-they long necks further .

" Look down into the crevice at [your]0-i feet , í [they]1823-they said . "[1727-the hunter] See what lie there white bones ! As brave and strong a man as [you]0-i climbed to these rocks.í And [he]0-i looked up . [He]0-i saw there was no use ; [he]0-i would never hold [Truth]149-truth , never see [her]149-truth , never find [her]149-truth . So [he]0-i lay down here , for [he]0-i was very tired . [He]0-i went to sleep for ever . [He]0-i put [himself]0-i to sleep . Sleep is very tranquil . [You]1824-you are not lonely when [you]1824-you

are asleep , neither do [your]1824-you hands ache , nor [your]1824-you heart . And [the hunter]1727-the hunter laughed between [his]1727-the hunter teeth.í And [the hunter]1727-the hunter laughed between [his]1727-the hunter teeth .

" Have [I]1727-the hunter torn from [my]1727-the hunter heart all that was dearest ; have [I]1727-the hunter wandered alone in the land of night ; have [I]1727-the hunter resisted temptation ; have [I]1727-the hunter dwelt where the voice of [[my]1727-the hunter kind]4196-my kind is never heard , and laboured alone , to lie down and be food for [you]1824-you , [ye]1824-you harpies?í [He]1727-the hunter laughed fiercely ; and the Echoes of [Despair]154-despair slunk away , for the laugh of a brave , strong heart is as a death blow to [them]1827-they . Nevertheless [they]1827-they crept out again and looked at [him]1727-the hunter . "[1727-the hunter] Do [you]1727-the hunter know that [your]1727-the hunter hair is white?í [they]1827-they said , " that [your]1727-the hunter hands begin to tremble like [a child]224-a child 's ? Do [you]1727-the hunter see that the point of [your]1727-the hunter shuttle is gone ? it is cracked already . If [you]1727-the hunter should ever climb [this stair]4198-this stair , í [they]1827-they said , "[1840-her] it will be [your]1727-the hunter last . [You]1727-the hunter will never climb another.í

And [he]1727-the hunter answered , " [I]1813-other men know it ! í and worked on .[1813-other men]

[The old , thin hands]1828-the old , thin hands cut the stones ill and jaggedly , for the fingers were stiff and bent . The beauty and the strength of [the man]372-the man was gone . At last , [an old , wizened , shrunken face]1830-an old , wizened , shrunken face looked out above [the rocks]1831-the rocks . It saw [the eternal mountains]1832-the eternal mountains rise with walls to the white clouds ; but its work was done . [The old hunter]1833-the old hunter folded [his]1833-the old hunter tired hands and lay down by the precipice where [he]1833-the old hunter had worked away [his]1833-the old hunter life . It was the sleeping time at last . Below [him]1833-the old hunter over [the valleys]1820-the valleys rolled the thick white mist . Once it broke ; and through the gap the dying eyes looked down on the trees and fields of [their]1835-their childhood . From afar seemed borne to [him]1833-the old hunter the cry of [his]1833-the old hunter own wild birds , and [he]1833-the old hunter heard the noise of [people]249-people singing as [they]249-people danced . And [he]1833-the old hunter thought [he]1833-the old hunter heard among [them]249-people the voices of [[his]1833-the old hunter old comrades]1837-his old comrades ; and [he]1833-the old hunter saw far off the sunlight shine on [[his]1833-the old hunter early home]1838-his early home . And great tears gathered in [the hunter]1727-the hunter 's eyes .

" Ah ! [they who die there do not die alone]4199-they who die there do not die alone , í [he]0-i cried . Then the mists rolled together again ; and [he]0-i turned [his]0-i eyes away .[1845-the dying man]

" [I]0-i have sought , í [he]0-i said , "[0-i] for long years [I]0-i have laboured ; but [I]0-i have not found [her]1840-her . [I]0-i have not rested , [I]0-i have not repined , and [I]0-i have not seen [her]1840-her ; now [my]0-i strength is gone . Where [I]0-i lie down worn out [other men]1813-other men will stand , young and fresh . By the steps that [I]0-i have cut [they]1813-other men will climb ; by the stairs that [I]0-i have built [they]1813-other men will mount . [They]1813-other men will never know the name of [the man who made [them]1813-other men]1842-the man who made them . At the clumsy work [they]1813-other men will laugh ; when the stones roll [they]1813-other men will curse [me]0-i . But [they]1813-other men will mount , and on [my]0-i work ; [they]1813-other men will climb , and by [my]0-i stair ! [They]1813-other men will find [her]1840-her , and through [me]0-i ! And [no man]339-no man liveth to [himself]339-no man , and [no man]339-no man dieth to himself.í

The tears rolled from beneath the shrivelled eyelids . If [Truth]149-truth had appeared above [him]0-i

in the clouds now [he]0-i could not have seen [her]1840-her .

" [[My]0-i soul]4200-my soul hears [their]1813-other men glad step coming , í [he]0-i said ; "[0-i] and [they]1813-other men shall mount ! [they]1813-other men shall mount!í [He]0-i raised [his]0-i shrivelled hand to [his]0-i eyes . Then slowly from the white sky above , through the still air , came something falling , falling , falling . Softly it fluttered down , and dropped on to the breast of [the dying man]1845-the dying man . [He]0-i felt it with [his]0-i hands . It was a feather . [He]1845-the dying man died holding it . " [The boy]234-the boy had shaded [his]234-the boy eyes with [his]234-the boy hand . On the wood of the carving great drops fell . [The stranger]418-the stranger must have laughed outright , or remained silent and somewhat solemn . "[418-the stranger] How did [you]0-i know it ? " [the boy]234-the boy whispered at last . "[418-the stranger] It is not written there not on that wood . How did [you]0-i know it ? "[3470-men]

" Certainly , "[242-a man] said [the stranger]418-the stranger , " the whole of the story is not written here , but it is suggested . And the attribute of all true art , the highest and[234-the boy]

the lowest , is this that it says more than it says , and takes [you]1847-you away from itself . It is a little door that opens into [an infinite hall]1848-an infinite hall where [you]1847-you may find what [you]1847-you please . [Men]3470-men , thinking to detract , say , " [People]249-people read more in this or that work of genius than was ever written in it , í not perceiving that [they]249-people pay the highest compliment . If [we]4205-we pick up the finger and nail of [a real man]4206-a real man , [we]4205-we can decipher a whole story could almost reconstruct the creature again , from head to foot . But half the body of [a Mumboo - jumbow idol]4207-a mumboo - jumbow idol leaves [us]4205-we utterly in the dark as to what the rest was like . [We]4205-we see what [we]4205-we see , but nothing more . There is nothing so universally intelligible as truth . It has a thousand meanings , and suggests a thousand more , all true . Though [a man]242-a man should carve it into matter with the least possible manipulative skill , it will yet find [interpreters]4209-interpreters . It is the soul that looks out with burning eyes through the most gross fleshly filament . It is that which is universal . Whosoever should[418-the stranger]

portray truly the life and death of a little flower , its birth , sucking in of nourishment , waxing , reproduction of its kind , withering and vanishing , would have shaped a symbol of all existence . All true facts of nature or the mind are related . [Your]1847-you little carving represents a mental fact as it really is , therefore fifty different true stories might be read from it . What [your]1847-you work wants is not truth , but beauty of external form , the other half of art . Skill may come in time , but [you]1847-you will have to work hard . The love of beauty and the desire for it must be born in [a man]242-a man ; the skill to reproduce it [he]242-a man must make . "[234-the boy]

Having delivered [himself]242-a man of these paradoxes , for the purpose of observing their effect upon [[his]242-a man listener]1851-his listener , [the stranger]418-the stranger broke off the end of a cigar and lit it . " All [my]234-the boy life [I]234-the boy have longed to see [you]418-the stranger , "[234-the boy] [the boy]234-the boy said .

[He]234-the boy lifted the heavy wood from [the stranger]418-the stranger 's knee and drew yet nearer [him]418-the stranger . In the dog - like

manner of [his]242-a man drawing near there was something superbly ridiculous , unless [one]324-one chanced to view it in another light . Presently [the stranger]418-the stranger said , whiffing , " Do something for [me]234-the boy . "[234-the boy]

[The boy]234-the boy started up . " No ; stay where [you]418-the stranger are . [I]234-the boy do n't want [you]418-the stranger to go anywhere ; [I]234-the boy want [you]418-the stranger to talk to [me]234-the boy . " [I]418-the stranger have never done anything , "[418-the stranger] [he]234-the boy said . " Then tell [me]418-the stranger of that nothing . What was the first thing [you]418-the stranger ever wanted very much ? "[418-the stranger]

[The boy]234-the boy waited to remember , then began

hesitatingly , but soon the words flowed . In the smallest past [we]1864-we find an inexhaustible mine when once [we]1864-we begin to dig at it . [We]1864-we stare [ourselves]1864-we at the things [we]1864-we draw forth when for another [we]1864-we disturb the days of old .

A confused , disordered story it was the little made large and the large small , and nothing showing its inward meaning . It is not till the past has receded many steps that before the clearest eyes it falls into co - ordinate pictures . It is not till the [I]0-i [we]1864-we tell of has ceased to exist , that it takes its place among other objective realities , and finds its true niche in the picture . The present and [the near past]1865-the near past is a confusion , whose meaning flashes on [us]1864-we as it slinks away into the distance . [The stranger]418-the stranger lit one cigar from the end of another , and puffed and listened , with half - closed eyes . " [I]418-the stranger will remember more to tell [you]418-the stranger if [you]418-the stranger like , "[418-the stranger] said [the boy]234-the boy .

[He]234-the boy spoke with that extreme gravity common to [all very young things who feel deeply]1868-all very young things who feel deeply . "[1885-she] [Waldo]60-waldo looked at [him]234-the boy . Was [[his]234-the boy delightful one]1873-his delightful one ridiculing [him]234-the boy ? " Yes , "[1885-she] [he]418-the stranger said ; " here with the karroo - bushes and red sand . [You]60-waldo wonder what [I]1894-the speaker mean ? To [all who have been born in the old faith]4213-all who have been born in the old faith there comes a time of danger , when the old slips from [us]1879-we , and [we]1879-we have not yet planted [our]1879-we feet on the new ; when the voice from [Sinai]155-sinai[1894-the speaker]

thunders no more , and the still small voice of reason is not yet heard . [We]1879-we have proved the religion [[our]1879-we mothers]1880-our mothers fed [us]1879-we on to be a delusion ; in [our]1879-we bewilderment [we]1879-we see no rule by which to guide [our]1879-we steps day by day ; and yet every day [we]1879-we must step somewhere . [We]1879-we have never once been taught by word or act to distinguish between religion and the moral laws on which it has artfully fastened itself , and from which it has sucked its vitality . When [we]1879-we have dragged down the weeds and creepers that covered the solid wall and have found them to be rotten wood , [we]1879-we imagine the wall itself to be rotten wood too . [We]1879-we find it is solid and standing only when [we]1879-we fall headlong against [it]1881-it . [We]1879-we have been taught that all right and wrong originate in the will of [an irresponsible being]1882-an irresponsible being . It is some time before [we]1879-we see how the inexorable " [Thou]4214-thou shalt and shalt not , í are carved into the nature of things . This is the time of danger .[1894-the speaker]

" In the end experience will inevitably teach[1894-the speaker]

[us]1879-we that the laws for a wise and noble life have a foundation infinitely deeper than the fiat of [any being]1883-any being , [God]56-god or [man]329-man , even in the groundwork of human nature . [She]1885-she will teach [us]1879-we that whoso sheddeth [man]329-man 's blood , though by [man]329-man [his]329-man blood be not shed , though [no man]339-no man avenge and no hell await ; yet every drop shall blister on [his]329-man soul and eat in the name of the dead . [She]1885-she will teach that whoso takes a love not lawfully [his]329-man own , gathers a flower with a poison on its petals ; that whoso revenges , strikes with a sword that has two edges one for [[his]329-man adversary]1889-his adversary , one for [himself]329-man ; that who lives to [himself]329-man is dead , though the ground is not yet on [him]329-man ; that who wrongs another clouds [his]329-man own sun ; and [that who sins in secret]1890-that who sins in secret stands accursed and condemned before [the one Judge who deals eternal justice [his]1891-the one judge who deals eternal justice his own all - knowing self own all - knowing self]1891-the one judge who deals eternal justice his own all - knowing self .

" Experience will teach [us]1879-we this , and reason will show [us]1879-we why it must be so ; but at first [the world]252-the world swings before [our]1879-we eyes , and no voice cries[1892-his]

out , " This is the way , walk [ye]4216-you in it!í Boy , [you]4216-you are happy to be here ! When the suspense fills [you]4216-you with pain [you]4216-you build stone walls and dig earth for relief . [Others]4156-others have stood where [you]4216-you stand to - day , and have felt as [you]4216-you feel ; and another relief has been offered [them]4156-others , and [they]4156-others have taken it .[1893-the listener]

" When the day has come when [they]4156-others have seen the path in which [they]4156-others might walk , [they]4156-others have not the strength to follow it . Habits have fastened on [them]4156-others from which nothing but death can free [them]4156-others ; which cling closer than [his]1892-his sacerdotal sanctimony to [a priest]294-a priest ; which feed on the intellect like a worm sapping energy , hope , creative power , resolution , all that makes [a man higher than a beast leaving only the power to yearn , to regret , and to sink lower in the abyss]4219-a man higher than a beast leaving only the power to yearn , to regret , and to sink lower in the abyss .[1894-the speaker]

" [Boy]3767-boy , "[418-the stranger] [he]1892-his said , and [the listener]1893-the listener was not more unsmiling now than [the speaker]1894-the speaker , " [you]3767-boy are happy to be [here]3430-here ! " Lead [us]4222-we not into temptation.í Live on here quietly . The time may yet come when [you]3767-boy will be that which [other men]1813-other men have hoped to be and never will be now . "[418-the stranger]

[The stranger]418-the stranger rose , shook the dust from [his]418-the stranger sleeve , and half - ashamed of [his]418-the stranger earnestness , looked across the bushes for [[his]418-the stranger horse]1896-his horse . " [We]4222-we should have been on [our]4222-we way already , "[418-the stranger] [he]418-the stranger said . " [We]4222-we shall have a long ride in the dark to - night . " It may be of some help to [you]234-the boy . It was a gospel to [me]234-the boy when [I]234-the boy first fell on it . [You]234-the boy must not expect too much , "[234-the boy] [he]418-the stranger said ; " but it may give [you]234-the boy a centre round which to organize[234-the boy]

[He]418-the stranger smiled [his]418-the stranger automaton smile , and rebuttoned the bag . " Well , [I]4108-the new man trust [we]4224-we shall meet again some day , sooner or later . "[4108-the new man]

[He]60-waldo shook hands with the ungloved hand ; then drew on the glove , touched [his]60-waldo horse , and

rode slowly away . [The boy]234-the boy stood to watch [him]60-waldo .

Once when [the stranger]418-the stranger had gone half across [the plain]196-the plain [he]60-waldo looked back . " [Poor devil]4225-poor devil , "[4108-the new man] [he]60-waldo said , smiling and stroking [his]60-waldo moustache .
