" [People]249-people say , forget , forget ! "[2684-he] [he]2684-he cried , pacing [the room]215-the room . " [They]249-people are mad ! [they]249-people are [fools]1457-fools ! Do [they]249-people say so to [men who are dying of thirst]4715-men who are dying of thirst forget , forget ? Why is it only to [us]4716-us [they]249-people say[156-gregory]

so ? It is a lie to say that time makes it easy ; it is afterward , afterward that it eats in at [your]2686-you heart !

" All these months , "[0-i] [he]2684-he cried bitterly , " [I]0-i have lived [here]3430-here quietly , day after day , as if [I]0-i cared for what [I]0-i ate , and what [I]0-i drank , and what [I]0-i did ! [I]0-i care for nothing ! [I]0-i can not bear it ! [I]0-i will not ! Forget ! forget ! "[0-i] ejaculated [Gregory]156-gregory . " [You]2686-you can forget all [the world]252-the world , but [you]2686-you can not forget [yourself]2686-you . When one thing is more to [you]2686-you than [yourself]2686-you , how are [you]2686-you to forget it ? "[2689-he] [I]0-i read , " [he]0-i said "[2689-he] yes ; and then [I]0-i come to a word [she]2687-she used , and it is all back with [me]0-i again ! [I]0-i go to count [my]0-i sheep , and [I]0-i see [her]2687-she face before [me]0-i , and [I]0-i stand and let the sheep run by . [I]0-i look at [you]2688-your , and in [your]2688-your smile , a something at the corner of [your]2688-your lips , [I]0-i see [her]2687-she . How can [I]0-i forget [her]2687-she when , whenever [I]0-i turn , [she]2687-she is there , and not there ? [I]0-i can not , [I]0-i will not , live where [I]0-i do not see [her]2687-she .

" [I]111-the kaffirs know what [you]2687-she think , "[111-the kaffirs] [he]0-i said , turning upon [her]2687-she . " [You]2687-she think [I]54-em am mad ; [you]2687-she think [I]54-em am going to see whether [she]2687-she will not like [me]54-em ! [I]54-em am not so foolish . [I]54-em should have known at first [she]2687-she never could suffer [me]54-em . Who am [I]54-em , what am [I]54-em , that [she]2687-she should look at [me]54-em ? It was right that [she]2687-she left [me]54-em ; right that [she]2687-she should not look at [me]54-em . If [any one]504-any one says it is not , it is a lie ! [I]54-em am not going to speak to [her]2687-she , "[54-em] [he]2689-he added " only to see [her]2687-she ; only to stand sometimes in a place where [she]2687-she has stood before . "[54-em]

CHAPTER XI . AN UNFINISHED LETTER .

[GREGORY ROSE]156-gregory had been gone seven months . [Em]54-em sat alone on a white sheepskin before the fire .

The August night - wind , weird and shrill , howled round the chimneys and through the crannies , and in walls and doors , and uttered a long low cry as it forced its way among the clefts of the stones on the " kopje . "[54-em] It was a wild night . The prickly pear tree , stiff and upright as it held [its]2690-its arms , felt the wind 's might , and knocked its flat leaves heavily together , till great branches broke off . [The Kaffirs]111-the kaffirs , as [they]111-the kaffirs slept in [[their]111-the kaffirs straw huts]2691-their straw huts ,

whispered one to another that before morning there would not be an armful of thatch left on the roofs ; and the beams of [the waggon - house]229-the waggon - house creaked and groaned as if it were heavy work to resist the importunity of the wind .

[Em]54-em had not gone to bed . Who could sleep on a night like this ? So in [the dining room]1311-the dining room [she]54-em had lighted a fire , and sat on the ground before it , turning the roaster - cakes that lay on the coals to bake . It would save work in the morning ; and [she]54-em blew out the light because the wind through the window - chinks made it flicker and run ; and [she]54-em sat singing to [herself]54-em as [she]54-em watched the cakes . [They]2694-they lay at one end of the wide hearth on a bed of coals , and at the other end a fire burnt up steadily , casting its amber glow over [Em]54-em 's light hair and black dress , with the ruffle of crape about the neck , and over the white curls of the sheepskin on which [she]54-em sat .

Louder and more fiercely yet howled the

storm ; but [Em]54-em sang on , and heard nothing but the words of [her]54-em song , and heard them only faintly , as something restful . It was an old , childish song [she]54-em had often heard [[her]54-em mother]2695-her mother sing long ago

" Where the reeds dance by [the river]3513-the river , Where the willow 's song is said , On the face of the morning water , Is reflected a white flower 's head . "[2697-a tall man]

[She]54-em folded [her]54-em hands and sang the next verse dreamily

" Where the reeds shake by [the river]3513-the river , Where the moonlight 's sheen is shed , On the face of the sleeping water , Two leaves of a white flower float dead . Dead , dead , dead ! "[2697-a tall man]

[She]54-em echoed the refrain softly till it died away , and then repeated it . It was as if , unknown to [herself]54-em , it harmonized with the pictures and thoughts that sat with [her]54-em there alone in the firelight . [She]54-em turned the cakes over , while the

wind hurled down a row of bricks from the gable , and made the walls tremble .

Presently [she]54-em paused and listened ; there was a sound as of something knocking at the back - doorway . But the wind had raised its level higher , and [she]54-em went on with [her]54-em work . At last the sound was repeated . Then [she]54-em rose , lit the candle and the fire , and went to see . Only to satisfy [herself]54-em , [she]54-em said , that nothing could be out on such a night . [She]54-em opened the door a little way , and held the light behind [her]54-em to defend it from the wind . [The figure of [a tall man]2697-a tall man]2696-the figure of a tall man stood there , and before [she]54-em could speak [he]2697-a tall man had pushed [his]2697-a tall man way in , and was forcing the door to close behind [him]2697-a tall man . " [Waldo]60-waldo ! "[0-i] [she]54-em cried in astonishment . [He]2697-a tall man had been gone more than a year and a half .

" [You]54-em did not expect to see [me]54-em , "[54-em] [he]2697-a tall man answered , as [he]2697-a tall man turned toward [her]54-em ; " [I]54-em should have slept in [the out - house]4722-the out - house , and not troubled [you]54-em to - night ;[54-em]

but through the shutter [I]0-i saw glimmerings of a light . "[2697-a tall man]

" Come in to the fire , "[2697-a tall man] [she]54-em said ; " it is a terrific night for any creature to be out . Shall [we]4723-we not go and fetch [your]2697-a tall man things in first ? "[2697-a tall man] [she]54-em added . " [I]54-em have nothing but this , "[54-em] [he]2697-a tall man said , motioning to the little bundle in [his]2697-a tall man hand . " [Your]54-em horse ? "[54-em] " Is dead . "[2697-a tall man] [He]2697-a tall man sat down on the bench before the fire . " The cakes are almost ready , "[2697-a tall man] [she]54-em said ; " [I]2697-a tall man will get [you]2697-a tall man something to eat . Where have [you]2697-a tall man been wandering all this while ? "[2697-a tall man] " Up and down , up and down , "[54-em] [he]2697-a tall man answered wearily ; " and now the whim has seized [me]2697-a tall man to come back here . [Em]54-em , "[2697-a tall man] [he]2697-a tall man said , putting [his]2697-a tall man hand on [her]54-em arm as [she]54-em passed [him]2697-a tall man , " have [you]54-em heard from [Lyndall]59-lyndall lately ? "[2697-a tall man] " Yes , "[2697-a tall man] said [Em]54-em , turning quickly from [him]2697-a tall man .

" Where is [she]59-lyndall ? [I]54-em had one letter from [her]59-lyndall , but that is almost eighteen months ago now just when [she]59-lyndall left . Where is [she]59-lyndall ? "[54-em] " In [the Transvaal]48-the transvaal . [I]54-em will go and get [you]2697-a tall man some supper ; [we]4724-we can talk afterward . "[54-em] " Can [you]2697-a tall man give [me]457-his companion [her]59-lyndall exact address ? [I]457-his companion want to write to [her]59-lyndall . "[457-his companion] But [Em]54-em had gone into [the next room]221-the next room . When food was on the table [she]54-em knelt down before the fire , turning the cakes , babbling restlessly , eagerly , now of this , now of that . [She]54-em was glad to see [him]2697-a tall man [Tant ' Sannie]53-tant ' sannie was coming soon to show [her]54-em [[her]54-em new baby]2699-her new baby [he]2697-a tall man must stay on [the farm]260-the farm now , and help [her]54-em . And [Waldo]60-waldo [himself]60-waldo was well content to eat [his]60-waldo meal in silence , asking no more questions . " [Gregory]156-gregory is coming back next week , "[54-em] [she]54-em said ; " [he]156-gregory will have been gone just a hundred and three days to - morrow . [I]54-em had a letter from [him]156-gregory yesterday . "[54-em]

" Where has [he]156-gregory been ? "[2697-a tall man] But [[his]2697-a tall man companion]457-his companion stooped to lift a cake from the fire . " How the wind blows ! [One]324-one can hardly hear [one]324-one 's own voice , "[2697-a tall man] [she]54-em said . " Take this warm cake ; [no one]237-no one 's cakes are like [mine]54-em . Why , [you]2697-a tall man have eaten nothing ! "[2697-a tall man] " [I]2697-a tall man am a little weary , "[2697-a tall man] [he]2697-a tall man said ; " the wind was mad to - night . "[2697-a tall man] [He]2697-a tall man folded [his]2697-a tall man arms , and rested [his]2697-a tall man head against the fire - place , whilst [she]54-em removed the dishes from the table . On the mantel - piece stood an ink - pot and some sheets of paper . Presently [he]2697-a tall man took them down and turned up the corner of the table - cloth . " [I]2706-my master will write a few lines , "[2706-my master] [he]2697-a tall man said ; " till [you]54-em are ready to sit down and talk . "[2706-my master]

[Em]54-em , as [she]54-em shook out the table - cloth , watched [him]2697-a tall man bending intently over [his]2697-a tall man paper . [He]2697-a tall man had changed much . [His]2697-a tall man face had grown

thinner ; [his]2697-a tall man cheeks were almost hollow , though they were covered by a dark growth of beard .

[She]54-em sat down on the skin beside [him]2697-a tall man , and felt the little bundle on the bench ; it was painfully small and soft . Perhaps it held a shirt and a book , but nothing more . The old black hat had a piece of unhemmed muslin twisted round it , and on [his]2697-a tall man elbow was a large patch so fixed on with yellow thread that [[her]54-em woman]2702-her woman 's heart ached . Only [his]2697-a tall man hair was not changed , and hung in silky beautiful waves almost to [his]2697-a tall man shoulders . To - morrow [she]54-em would take the ragged edge off [his]2697-a tall man collar , and put a new band round [his]2697-a tall man hat . [She]54-em did not interrupt [him]2697-a tall man , but [she]54-em wondered how it was that [he]2697-a tall man sat to write so intently after [his]2697-a tall man long weary walk . [He]2697-a tall man was not tired now ; [his]2697-a tall man pen hurried quickly and restlessly over the paper , and [his]2697-a tall man eye was bright . Presently [Em]54-em raised [her]54-em hand to [her]54-em breast , where lay the letter yesterday had brought

[her]54-em . Soon [she]54-em had forgotten [him]2697-a tall man , as entirely as [he]2697-a tall man had forgotten [her]54-em ; each was in [[his]2697-a tall man own world]2703-his own world with [his]2697-a tall man own . [He]2697-a tall man was writing to [Lyndall]59-lyndall . [He]2697-a tall man would tell [her]54-em all [he]2697-a tall man had seen , all [he]2697-a tall man had done , though it were nothing worth relating . [He]2697-a tall man seemed to have come back to [her]54-em , and to be talking to [her]54-em now [he]2697-a tall man sat there in [the old house]2704-the old house .

" and then [I]0-i got to [the next town]4728-the next town , and [my]0-i horse was tired , so [I]0-i could go no further , and looked for work . [A shop - keeper]4729-a shop - keeper agreed to hire [me]0-i as [salesman]4730-salesman . [He]4729-a shop - keeper made [me]0-i sign a promise to remain six months , and [he]4729-a shop - keeper gave [me]0-i [a little empty room at the back of [the store]4732-the store]4731-a little empty room at the back of the store to sleep in . [I]0-i had still three pounds of [my]0-i own , and when [you]2705-you just come from [the country]4733-the country three pounds seems a great deal .[0-i]

" When [I]2709-he had been in [the shop]4734-the shop three days [I]2709-he wanted to go away again . [A clerk in [a shop]4736-a shop]4735-a clerk in a shop has the lowest work to do of [all the people]3466-all the people . It is[2709-he]

much better to break stones ; [you]2705-you have the blue sky above [you]2705-you , and only the stones to bend to . [I]0-i asked [[my]0-i master]2706-my master to let [me]0-i go , and [I]0-i offered to give [him]2706-my master [my]0-i two pounds , and the bag of mealies [I]0-i had bought with the other pound ; but [he]2706-my master would not .

" [I]2709-he found out afterward [he]2706-my master was only giving [me]2709-he half as much as [he]2706-my master gave to [the others]4738-the others that was why . [I]2709-he had fear when [I]2709-he looked at the other clerks that [I]2709-he would at last become like [them]4738-the others . All day [they]4738-the others were bowing and smirking to [the women who came in]4739-the women who came in ; smiling , when all [they]4738-the others wanted was to get [their]4738-the others money from [them]4738-the others . [They]4738-the others used to run and fetch the dresses and ribbons to show [them]4738-the others , and [they]4738-the others seemed to [me]2709-he like worms with oil on . There was one respectable thing in [that store]4740-that store it was [the Kaffir storeman]4741-the kaffir storeman . [His]4741-the kaffir storeman work was to load and unload , and [he]4741-the kaffir storeman never needed to smile except when [he]4741-the kaffir storeman liked , and [he]4741-the kaffir storeman never told lies .[2709-he]

" [The other clerks]4742-the other clerks gave [me]2709-he the name of [Old Salvation]180-old salvation ; but there was [one person]4743-one person [I]2709-he liked very much . [He]4743-one person was clerk in [another store]4744-another store . [He]4743-one person often went past the door . [He]4743-one person seemed to [me]2709-he not like [others]4156-others [his]4743-one person face was bright and fresh like [a little child]3461-a little child 's . When [he]4743-one person came to [the shop]4734-the shop [I]2709-he felt [I]2709-he liked [him]4743-one person . One day [I]2709-he saw a book in [his]4743-one person pocket , and that , made [me]2709-he feel near [him]4743-one person . [I]2709-he asked [him]4743-one person if [he]4743-one person was fond of reading , and [he]4743-one person said , yes , when there was nothing else to do . The next day [he]4743-one person came to [me]2709-he , and asked [me]2709-he if [I]2709-he did not feel lonely ; [he]4743-one person never saw [me]2709-he going out with [the other fellows]4748-the other fellows ; [he]4743-one person would come and see [me]2709-he that evening , [he]4743-one person said . "[2709-he] [I]0-i was glad , and bought some meat and flour , because [the grey mare]1117-the grey mare and [I]0-i always ate mealies ; it is the cheapest thing ; and if [you]2708-you boil it hard [you]2708-you ca n't eat much of it . [I]0-i made some cakes , and [I]0-i folded [my]0-i great coat on the box to make it softer for [him]2709-he ; and at last [he]2709-he came .

" "[2709-he] [You]2708-you 've got [a rummy place here]2710-a rummy place here , í [he]2709-he said . " [You]2708-you see there was nothing in it but packing - cases for furniture , and [it]2710-a rummy place here was rather empty . While [I]2709-he was putting the food on the box [he]2709-he looked at [my]2709-he books ; [he]2709-he read their names out aloud . "[2709-he] Elementary Physiology , í " First Principles.í "[2709-he] " Golly!í [he]2709-he said ; "[2709-he] [I]0-i 've got a lot of dry stuff like that at [home]302-home [I]0-i got for Sunday School prizes ; but [I]0-i only keep them to light [my]0-i pipe with now ; they come in handy for that.í Then [he]2709-he asked [me]0-i if [I]0-i had ever read a book called the " Black - eyed Creole.í "[2709-he] That is the style for [me]0-i , í [he]2709-he said ; " there where [the fellow]400-the fellow takes [the nigger - girl]4750-the nigger - girl by the arm , and [the other fellow]4751-the other fellow cuts it off ! That 's what [I]2709-he like.í "[2709-he] But what [he]2709-he said after that [I]0-i do n't remember , only it made [me]0-i feel as if [I]0-i were having a bad dream , and [I]0-i wanted to be far away .

" When [he]2709-he had finished eating [he]2709-he did not[2709-he]

stay long ; [he]2709-he had to go and see [some girls]2712-some girls [home]302-home from a prayer - meeting ; and [he]2709-he asked how it was [he]2709-he never saw [me]0-i walking out with any on Sunday afternoons . [He]2709-he said [he]2709-he had lots of [sweethearts]2714-sweethearts , and [he]2709-he was going to see one the next Wednesday on [a farm]3970-a farm , and [he]2709-he asked [me]0-i to lend [my]0-i mare . [I]0-i told [him]2709-he [she]2716-her was very old . But [he]2709-he said it did n't matter ; [he]2709-he would come the next day to fetch [her]2716-her .

" After [he]2709-he was gone [[my]0-i little room]4752-my little room got back to its old look . [I]0-i loved it so ; [I]0-i was so glad to get into it at night , and it seemed to be reproaching [me]0-i for bringing [him]2709-he [there]317-there . The next day [he]2709-he took the grey mare . On Thursday [he]2709-he did not bring [her]2716-her back , and on Friday [I]0-i found the saddle and bridle standing at [my]0-i door . "[0-i] In the afternoon [he]2709-he looked into [the shop]4734-the shop , and called out ,

" "[2723-i] Hope [you]2718-you got [your]2718-you saddle , [Farber]60-waldo . [Your]2718-you bag - of - bones kicked out six miles from here . [I]0-i 'll send [you]2718-you a couple of shillings to - morrow ,

though the old hide was n't worth it . Good morning.í

" But [I]2723-i sprung over the counter , and got [him]2709-he by [his]2709-he throat . [[My]2723-i father]3420-my father was so gentle with [her]2716-her ; [he]3420-my father never would ride [her]2716-her up [- hill]4755-- hill , and now [this fellow]4756-this fellow had murdered [her]2716-her ! [I]2723-i asked [him]2709-he where [he]2709-he had killed [her]2716-her , and [I]2723-i shook [him]2709-he till [he]2709-he slipped out of [my]2723-i hand . [He]2709-he stood in the door grinning .[2723-i]

" "[2723-i] It did n't take much to kill that bag - of - bones , whose master sleeps in a packing - case , and waits till [[his]2719-his company]4139-his company 's finished to eat on the plate . Should n't wonder if [you]2721-you fed [her]2722-her on sugar - bags , í [he]2723-i said ; " and if [you]2721-you think [I]2726-i 've jumped [her]2722-her , [you]2721-you 'd better go and look [yourself]2721-you . [You]2721-you 'll find [her]2722-her along [the road]888-the road by the "[2726-i] aas - vogels " that are eating her.í[2726-i]

" [I]2726-i caught [him]2709-he by [his]2709-he collar , and [I]2726-i lifted [him]2709-he from the ground , and [I]2726-i threw [him]2709-he out into [the street]1513-the street , half - way across it . [I]2726-i heard [the book - keeper]4759-the book - keeper say to [the clerk]4760-the clerk that there was always[2726-i]

the devil in [those mum fellows]2724-those mum fellows ; but [they]2724-those mum fellows never called [me]0-i Salvation after that .

" [I]2726-i am writing to [you]2721-you of very small things , but there is nothing else to tell ; it has been all small and [you]2721-you will like it . Whenever anything has happened [I]2726-i have always thought [I]2726-i would tell it to [you]2721-you . The back thought in [my]2726-i mind is always [you]2721-you . After that [only one old man]4761-only one old man came to visit [me]2726-i . [I]2726-i had seen [him]4761-only one old man in [the streets]4762-the streets often ; [he]4761-only one old man always wore very dirty black clothes , and a hat with crape round it , and [he]4761-only one old man had one eye , so [I]2726-i noticed [him]4761-only one old man . One day [he]4761-only one old man came to [[my]2726-i room]3536-my room with a subscription - list for [a minister]1947-a minister 's salary . When [I]2726-i said [I]2726-i had nothing to give [he]4761-only one old man looked at [me]2726-i with [his]4761-only one old man one eye .[2726-i]

" "[2732-a transport - rider 's waggons] [Young man]2725-young man , í [he]2726-i said , " how is it [I]0-i never see [you]2725-young man in [the house of the Lord?í]4765-the house of the lord?í [I]0-i thought [he]4761-only one old man was trying to do good , so [I]0-i felt sorry for [him]4761-only one old man , and [I]0-i told [him]4761-only one old man [I]0-i never went to [chapel]4766-chapel . "[0-i] [Young man]2725-young man , í [he]2726-i said , " it grieves [me]2738-we to hear such[2738-we]

godless words from the lips of [one so young so far gone in the paths of destruction]2728-one so young so far gone in the paths of destruction . [Young man]2725-young man , if [you]2725-young man forget [God]56-god , [God]56-god will forget [you]2725-young man . There is a seat on the right hand side as [you]2725-young man go at the bottom door that [you]2725-young man may get . If [you]2725-young man are given over to the enjoyment and frivolities of [this world]3439-this world , what will become of [your]2725-young man never - dying soul?í

" [He]4761-only one old man would not go till [I]234-the boy gave [him]4761-only one old man half - a - crown for [the minister]3957-the minister 's salary . Afterward [I]234-the boy heard [he]4761-only one old man was the man who collected the pew - rents , and got a per centage . [I]234-the boy did n't get to know [any one else]4268-any one else . "[234-the boy] When [my]0-i time in [that shop]2731-that shop was done [I]0-i hired [myself]0-i to drive one of [a transport - rider 's waggons]2732-a transport - rider 's waggons .

" That first morning , when [I]234-the boy sat in the front and called to [[my]234-the boy oxen]4769-my oxen , and saw nothing about [me]234-the boy but the hills with the blue coming down to them , and the karroo bushes , [I]234-the boy was drunk ; [I]234-the boy laughed ; [my]234-the boy heart was throbbing till it hurt[234-the boy]

[me]0-i . [I]0-i shut [my]0-i eyes tight , that when [I]0-i opened them [I]0-i might see there were no shelves about [me]0-i . There must be a beauty in buying and selling , if there is beauty in everything : but it is very ugly to [me]0-i . [My]0-i life as [transport - rider]2733-transport - rider would have been the best life in [the world]252-the world if [I]0-i had had only [one waggon to drive]2735-one waggon to drive . [[My]0-i master]2706-my master told [me]0-i [he]2706-my master would drive one , [I]0-i the other , and [he]2706-my master would hire [another person]2737-another person to drive the third . But the first day [I]0-i drove two to help [him]2706-my master , and after that [he]2706-my master let [me]0-i drive all three . Whenever [we]2738-we came to [an hotel]2739-an hotel [he]2706-my master stopped behind to get a drink , and when [he]2706-my master rode up to the waggons [he]2706-my master could never stand ; [the Hottentot]98-the hottentot and [I]0-i used to lift [him]2706-my master up . [We]2738-we always travelled all night , and used to " out - spaní for five or six hours in the heat of the day to rest . [I]0-i planned that [I]0-i would lie under a waggon and read for an hour or two every day before [I]0-i went to sleep , and [I]0-i did for the first[0-i]

two or three ; but after that [I]0-i only wanted to sleep , like the rest , and [I]0-i packed [my]0-i books away . When [you]2740-you have three waggons to look after all night , [you]2740-you are sometimes so tired [you]2740-you can hardly stand . At first when [I]0-i walked along driving [my]0-i waggons in the night it was glorious ; the stars had never looked so beautiful to [me]0-i ; and on the dark nights when [we]2738-we rode through the bush there were will - o'-the - wisps dancing on each side of [the road]888-the road . [I]0-i found out that even the damp and dark are beautiful . But [I]0-i soon changed , and saw nothing but [the road]888-the road and [my]0-i oxen . [I]0-i only wished for a smooth piece of [road]2743-road , so that [I]0-i might sit at the front and doze . At the places where [we]2738-we " out - spannedí there were sometimes rare plants and flowers , the festoons hanging from the bush - trees , nuts and insects , such as [we]2738-we never see here ; but after a little while [I]2762-the bushman - boy never looked at them [I]2762-the bushman - boy was too tired . [I]2762-the bushman - boy ate as much as [I]2762-the bushman - boy could , and then lay down on [my]2762-the bushman - boy[2762-the bushman - boy]

face under the waggon till [the boy]234-the boy came to wake [me]0-i to " in - span , í and then [we]2738-we drove on again all night ; so it went , so it went . [I]2762-the bushman - boy think sometimes when [I]2762-the bushman - boy walked by [[my]2762-the bushman - boy oxen]4769-my oxen [I]2762-the bushman - boy called to [them]4769-my oxen in [my]2762-the bushman - boy sleep , for [I]2762-the bushman - boy know [I]2762-the bushman - boy thought of nothing ; [I]2762-the bushman - boy was like an animal . [My]2762-the bushman - boy body was strong and well to work , but [my]2762-the bushman - boy brain was dead . If [you]4771-you have not felt it , [Lyndall]59-lyndall , [you]4771-you can not understand it . [You]4771-you may work , and work , and work , till [you]4771-you are only a body , not a soul . Now , when [I]2762-the bushman - boy see [one of those evil - looking men that come from [Europe]45-europe navvies , with the beast - like , sunken face , different from any [Kaffir]110-kaffir 's [I]2762-the bushman - boy know what brought that look into [their]4769-my oxen eyes]4772-one of those evil - looking men that come from europe navvies , with the beast - like , sunken face , different from any kaffir 's i know what brought that look into their eyes ; and if [I]2762-the bushman - boy have only one inch of tobacco [I]2762-the bushman - boy give [them]4769-my oxen half . It is work , grinding , mechanical work , that [they]4769-my oxen or [[their]4769-my oxen ancestors]4773-their ancestors have done , that has made [them]4769-my oxen into beasts . [You]2745-you may work [a man]242-a man 's body so that [his]242-a man soul dies . Work is good . [I]2762-the bushman - boy have worked at [the old farm]1373-the old farm from the[2762-the bushman - boy]

sun 's rising till its setting , but [I]0-i have had time to think , and time to feel . [You]2745-you may work [a man]242-a man so that all but the animal in [him]242-a man is gone ; and that grows stronger with physical labour . [You]2745-you may work [a man]242-a man till [he]242-a man is [a brute]2748-a brute . [I]0-i know it , because [I]0-i have felt it . [You]2745-you will never understand the change that came over [me]0-i . [No one]237-no one but [I]0-i will ever know how great it was . But [I]0-i was never miserable ; when [I]0-i could keep [my]0-i oxen from sticking fast , and when [I]0-i could find a place to lie down in , [I]0-i had all [I]0-i wanted . After [I]0-i had driven eight months a rainy season came . For eighteen hours out of the twenty - four [we]2750-we worked in the wet . The mud went up to the axles sometimes , and [we]2750-we had to dig the wheels out , and [we]2750-we never went far in a day . [[My]0-i master]2706-my master swore at [me]0-i more than ever , but when [he]2706-my master had done [he]2706-my master always offered [me]0-i [his]2706-my master brandy - flask . When [I]0-i first came [he]2706-my master had offered it [me]0-i , and [I]0-i had always refused ; but now [I]0-i

drank as [[my]0-i oxen]4769-my oxen did when [I]0-i gave [them]4769-my oxen water without thinking . At last [I]0-i bought brandy for [myself]0-i whenever [we]2750-we passed [an hotel]2739-an hotel .

" One Sunday [we]2750-we "[181-a german carrier] out - spannedí on [the banks of [a swollen river]2755-a swollen river]2754-the banks of a swollen river to wait for its going down . It was drizzling still , so [I]0-i lay under the waggon on the mud . There was [no dry place anywhere]2756-no dry place anywhere ; and all the dung was wet , so there was no fire to cook food . [My]0-i little flask was filled with brandy , and [I]0-i drank some and went to sleep . When [I]0-i woke it was drizzling still , so [I]0-i drank some more . [I]0-i was stiff and cold ; and [[my]0-i master]2706-my master , who lay by [me]0-i , offered [me]0-i [his]2706-my master flask , because mine was empty . [I]0-i drank some , and then [I]0-i thought [I]0-i would go and see if [the river]3513-the river was going down . [I]0-i remember that [I]0-i walked to [the road]888-the road , and it seemed to be going away from [me]0-i . When [I]0-i woke up [I]0-i was lying by a little bush on [the bank of [the river]3513-the river]3512-the bank of the river . It was afternoon ; all the clouds had gone , and the

sky was deep blue . [The Bushman - boy]2762-the bushman - boy was grilling ribs at the fire . [He]2762-the bushman - boy looked at [me]0-i and grinned from ear to ear . " [Master]4776-master was a little nice , í [he]2762-the bushman - boy said , "[4785-the one " spaní] and lay down in [the road]888-the road . Something might ride over [master]4430-master , so [I]0-i carried [him]4430-master there.í [He]2762-the bushman - boy grinned at [me]0-i again . It was as though [he]2762-the bushman - boy said , " [You]0-i and [I]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon are [comrades]4777-comrades . [I]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon have lain in [a road]4778-a road , too . [I]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon know all about it.í When [I]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon turned [my]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon head from [him]4776-master [I]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon saw [the earth]335-the earth , so pure after the rain , so green , so fresh , so blue ; and [I]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon was [a drunken carrier , whom [[his]4776-master leader]4781-his leader had picked up in the mud , and laid at the roadside to sleep out [his]4776-master drunken booze]4780-a drunken carrier , whom his leader had picked up in the mud , and laid at the roadside to sleep out his drunken booze . [I]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon remember [my]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon old life , and [I]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon remember [you]4782-you . [I]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon saw how , one day , [you]4782-you would read in the papers "[2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon] [A German Carrier]181-a german carrier , named [Waldo Farber]60-waldo , was killed through falling from [his]181-a german carrier waggon , being instantly crushed under the wheel . [Deceased]182-deceased was supposed to have been drunk at the time of the accident.í There

are those notices in the paper every month . [I]0-i sat up , and [I]0-i took the brandy - flask out of [my]0-i pocket , and [I]0-i flung it as far as [I]0-i could into the dark water . [The Hottentot boy]2765-the hottentot boy ran down to see if [he]2765-the hottentot boy could catch it ; it had sunk to the bottom . [I]0-i never drank again . But , [Lyndall]59-lyndall , sin looks much more terrible to [those who look at it]2766-those who look at it than to [those who do it]2767-those who do it . [A convict]2768-a convict , or [a man who drinks , seems something so far off and horrible when [we]2770-we see [him]181-a german carrier]2769-a man who drinks , seems something so far off and horrible when we see him ; but to [himself]181-a german carrier [he]181-a german carrier seems quite near to [us]2770-we , and like [us]2770-we . [We]2770-we wonder what kind of a creature [he]181-a german carrier is ; but [he]181-a german carrier is just [we]2770-we , [ourselves]2770-we . [We]2770-we are only the wood , the knife that carves on [us]2770-we is the circumstance .

" [I]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon do not know why [I]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon kept on working so hard for [that master]4783-that master . [I]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon think it was as [the oxen]1034-the oxen come every day and stand by the yokes ; [they]1034-the oxen do not know why . Perhaps [I]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon would have been with [him]4783-that master still ; but one day [we]2770-we started with[2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon]

loads for [the Diamond Fields]2771-the diamond fields . [The oxen]1034-the oxen were very thin now , and [they]1034-the oxen had been standing about in the yoke all day without food , while the waggons were being loaded . Not far from [the town]612-the town was [a hill]2774-a hill . When [we]2770-we came to the foot the first waggon stuck fast . [I]0-i tried for a little while to urge the oxen , but [I]0-i soon saw [the one " spaní]4785-the one " spaní could never pull it up . [I]2781-the transport - rider went to [the other waggon]4786-the other waggon to loosen that "[2781-the transport - rider] spaní to join [them]1034-the oxen on in front , but [the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon , jumped out .

" "[2781-the transport - rider] [They]1034-the oxen shall bring it up [the hill]2776-the hill ; and if [half of [them]1034-the oxen]2777-half of them die for it [they]1034-the oxen shall do it alone , í [he]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon said .

" [He]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon was not drunk , but in bad temper , for [he]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon had been drunk the night before . [He]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon swore at [me]1034-the oxen , and told [me]1034-the oxen to take the whip and help [him]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon . [We]4787-we tried for a little time , then [I]1034-the oxen told [him]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon it was no use , [they]1034-the oxen could never do it . [He]2775-the transport - rider , who was lying at the back of the waggon swore louder and called to [the leaders]4788-the leaders to come on with [their]1034-the oxen whips , and[1034-the oxen]

together [they]1034-the oxen lashed . There was one ox , a black ox , so thin that the ridge of [his]2778-his backbone almost cut through [his]2778-his flesh .

" "[2781-the transport - rider] It is [you]2779-you , [devil]2780-devil , is it , that will not pull?í [the transport - rider]2781-the transport - rider said . " [I]2781-the transport - rider will show [you]279-the boys something.í [He]2778-his glowered like a devil . "[2781-the transport - rider] [He]2781-the transport - rider told [the boys]279-the boys to leave off flogging , and [he]2781-the transport - rider held the ox by the horn , and took up a round stone and knocked its nose with it till the blood came . When [he]2781-the transport - rider had done [they]1034-the oxen called to [the oxen]1034-the oxen and took up [their]1034-the oxen whips again , and [the oxen]1034-the oxen strained with [their]1034-the oxen backs bent , but the waggon did not move an inch . " "[372-the man] So [you]2779-you wo n't , wo n't you?í [he]2781-the transport - rider said . " [I]1034-the oxen 'll help you.í[1034-the oxen]

" [He]1034-the oxen took out [his]1034-the oxen clasp - knife , and ran it into the leg of the trembling ox three times , up to the hilt . Then [he]1034-the oxen put the knife in [his]1034-the oxen pocket , and [they]1034-the oxen took [their]1034-the oxen whips . [The oxen]1034-the oxen 's flanks quivered , and they foamed at the mouth .[2806-i]

Straining , [they]1034-the oxen moved the waggon a few feet forward , then stood with bent backs to keep it from sliding back . From the black ox 's nostrils foam and blood were streaming on to the ground . [It]2785-it turned its head in its anguish and looked at [me]0-i with [its]2785-it great starting eyes . [It]2785-it was praying for help in its agony and weakness , and [they]1034-the oxen took [their]1034-the oxen whips again . [The creature]2786-the creature bellowed aloud . If there is [a God]724-a god , it was calling to [[its]2786-the creature Maker]2788-its maker for help . Then a stream of clear blood burst from both nostrils ; it fell on to the ground , and the waggon slipped back . [The man]372-the man walked up to it .

" "[2806-i] [You]372-the man are going to lie down , [devil]2780-devil , are [you]372-the man ? [We]1034-the oxen 'll see [you]372-the man do n't take it too easy.í

" The thing was just dying . [He]372-the man opened [his]372-the man clasp - knife and stooped down over it . [I]2806-i do not know what [I]2806-i did then . But afterward [I]2806-i know [I]2806-i had [him]372-the man on the stones , and [I]2806-i was kneeling on [him]372-the man . [The boys]279-the boys dragged [me]2806-i off . [I]2806-i wish [they]279-the boys[2806-i]

had not . [I]0-i left [him]372-the man standing in the sand in [the road]888-the road , shaking [himself]372-the man , and [I]0-i walked back to [the town]612-the town . [I]0-i took nothing from [that accursed waggon]2793-that accursed waggon , so [I]0-i had only two shillings . But it did not matter . The next day [I]0-i got work at [a wholesale store]2794-a wholesale store . [My]0-i work was to pack and unpack goods , and to carry boxes , and [I]0-i had to work from six in the morning to six in the evening ; so [I]0-i had plenty of time . [I]0-i hired [a little room]2795-a little room , and subscribed to [a library]2796-a library , so [I]0-i had everything [I]0-i needed ; and in the week of Christmas holidays [I]0-i went to see [the sea]3425-the sea . [I]0-i walked all night to escape the heat , and a little after sunrise [I]0-i got to [the top of [a high hill]2799-a high hill]2798-the top of a high hill . Before [me]0-i was [a long , low , blue , monotonous mountain]2800-a long , low , blue , monotonous mountain . [I]0-i walked looking at [it]2800-a long , low , blue , monotonous mountain , but [I]0-i was thinking of [the sea]3425-the sea [I]0-i wanted to see . At last [I]0-i wondered what that curious blue thing might be ; then it struck [me]0-i , it was [the sea]3425-the sea ! [I]0-i would have turned back again , only [I]0-i was too tired . [I]0-i

wonder if all the things [we]2803-we long to see [the churches]2804-the churches , the pictures , [the men in [Europe]45-europe]2805-the men in europe will disappoint [us]2803-we so ! [You]2806-i see [I]0-i had dreamed of it so long . When [I]0-i was [a little boy]2807-a little boy , minding sheep behind the " kopje;í [I]0-i used to see the waves stretching out as far as the eye could reach in the sunlight . [[My]0-i sea]4791-my sea ! Is the idea always more beautiful than the real ?[0-i]

" [I]2840-i got to [the beach]4792-the beach that afternoon , and [I]2840-i saw the water run up and down on the sand , and [I]2840-i saw the white foam breakers ; they were pretty , but [I]2840-i thought [I]2840-i would go back the next day . It was not [[my]2840-i sea]4791-my sea .[2840-i]

" But [I]2841-one of the ladies began to like it when [I]2841-one of the ladies sat by it that night in the moonlight ; and the next day [I]2841-one of the ladies liked it better ; and before [I]2841-one of the ladies left [I]2841-one of the ladies loved it . It was not like the sky and stars , that talk of what has no beginning and no end ; but it is so human . Of all the things [I]2841-one of the ladies have ever seen , only [the sea]3425-the sea is like [a human[2841-one of the ladies]

being]4300-a human being ; the sky is not , nor the earth . But [the sea]3425-the sea is always moving , always something deep in itself is stirring it . It never rests . It is always wanting , wanting , wanting . It hurries on ; and then it creeps back slowly without having reached , moaning . [It]3425-the sea is always asking a question , and it never gets the answer . [I]0-i can hear it in the day and in the night ; the white foam breakers are saying that which [I]0-i think . [I]0-i walk alone with [them]2809-them when there is [no one]237-no one to see [me]0-i , and [I]0-i sing with [them]2809-them . [I]0-i lie down on [the sand]287-the sand and watch [them]2809-them with [my]0-i eyes half shut . The sky is better , but it is so high above [our]2812-our heads . [I]0-i love [the sea]3425-the sea . Sometimes [we]2812-our must look down too . After five days [I]0-i went back to [the town]612-the town .

" [I]0-i had glorious books , and in the night [I]0-i could sit in [[my]0-i little room]4752-my little room and read them ; but [I]0-i was lonely . Books are not the same things when [you]4797-you are living among [people]249-people . [I]0-i can not tell[0-i]

why , but they are dead . On [the farm]260-the farm [they]2809-them would have been living beings to [me]0-i ; but here , where there were so many people about [me]0-i , [I]0-i wanted [some one]3445-some one to belong to [me]0-i . [I]0-i was lonely . [I]0-i wanted something that was flesh and blood . Once on [this farm]3442-this farm there came [a stranger]405-a stranger ; [I]0-i did not ask [his]405-a stranger name , but [he]405-a stranger sat among [the karroo]1510-the karroo and talked with [me]0-i . Now , wherever [I]0-i have travelled [I]0-i have looked for [him]405-a stranger in [hotels]2820-hotels , in [streets]2821-streets , in [passenger waggons]2822-passenger waggons as [they]2822-passenger waggons rushed in , through the open windows of [houses]2823-houses [I]0-i have looked for [him]405-a stranger , but [I]0-i have not found [him]405-a stranger never heard a voice like [his]405-a stranger . One day [I]0-i went to [the Botanic Gardens]2824-the botanic gardens . It was a half - holiday , and [the band]2825-the band was to play . [I]0-i stood in [the long raised avenue]2826-the long raised avenue and looked down . There were many flowers , and [ladies]2827-ladies and [children]3428-children were walking about beautifully dressed . At last the music began . [I]0-i had not heard such music before . At first it was slow and even , like the everyday life , when

[we]2829-we walk through it without thought or feeling ; then it grew faster , then it paused , hesitated , then it was quite still for an instant , and then it burst out . [Lyndall]59-lyndall , [they]2830-they made heaven right when [they]2830-they made it all music . It takes [you]2831-you up and carries [you]2831-you away , away , till [you]2831-you have the things [you]2831-you longed for ; [you]2831-you are in [their]2830-they own world . The walls about [you]2831-you break , and [you]2831-you spread out , [you]2831-you are shut in on no side . [I]0-i could not see anything while it was playing ; [I]0-i stood with [my]0-i head against [my]0-i tree ; but , when it was done , [I]0-i saw that there were [ladies]2827-ladies sitting close to [me]0-i on a wooden bench , and [the stranger who had talked to [me]0-i that day in [the karroo]1510-the karroo]2833-the stranger who had talked to me that day in the karroo was sitting between [them]2827-ladies . [The ladies]2835-the ladies were very pretty , and [their]2835-the ladies dresses beautiful . [I]0-i do not think [they]2835-the ladies had been listening to the music , for [they]2835-the ladies were talking and laughing very softly . [I]0-i heard all [they]2835-the ladies said , and could even smell the rose on the breast of one . [I]0-i was afraid [he]2833-the stranger who had talked to me that day in the karroo would

see [me]0-i ; so [I]0-i went to the other side of the tree , and soon [they]2835-the ladies got up and began to pace up and down in [the avenue]4697-the avenue . All the time the music played [they]2835-the ladies chatted , and [he]2833-the stranger who had talked to me that day in the karroo carried on [his]2833-the stranger who had talked to me that day in the karroo arm the scarf of [the prettiest lady]2837-the prettiest lady . [I]0-i did not hear the music ; [I]0-i tried to catch the sound of [his]2833-the stranger who had talked to me that day in the karroo voice each time [he]2833-the stranger who had talked to me that day in the karroo went by . When [I]0-i was listening to the music [I]0-i did not know [I]0-i was badly dressed ; now [I]0-i felt so ashamed of [myself]0-i . [I]0-i never knew before what a low , horrible thing [I]0-i , dressed in tancord , was . That day on [the farm]260-the farm , when [we]2839-we sat on the ground under the thorn - trees , [I]0-i thought [he]2833-the stranger who had talked to me that day in the karroo quite belonged to [me]0-i ; now , [I]0-i saw [he]2833-the stranger who had talked to me that day in the karroo was not [mine]0-i .

" At last [they]4799-they turned to go to the gate , and [I]0-i walked after [them]4799-they . When [they]4799-they got out [he]2833-the stranger who had talked to me that day in the karroo helped [the ladies]2835-the ladies into a phaeton , and stood for a moment with [his]2833-the stranger who had talked to me that day in the karroo foot on the step talking to [them]2835-the ladies . [He]2833-the stranger who had talked to me that day in the karroo had a little cane in [his]2833-the stranger who had talked to me that day in the karroo hand , and [an Italian greyhound]4801-an italian greyhound ran after [him]2833-the stranger who had talked to me that day in the karroo . Just when[0-i]

[they]2840-i drove away [one of [the ladies]2835-the ladies]2841-one of the ladies dropped [her]2841-one of the ladies whip .

" "[0-i] Pick it up , [fellow]2843-fellow , í [she]2841-one of the ladies said ; and when [I]0-i brought it [her]2841-one of the ladies [she]2841-one of the ladies threw sixpence on the ground . [I]0-i might have gone back to [the garden]2844-the garden then ; but [I]0-i did not want music ; [I]0-i wanted clothes , and to be fashionable and fine . [I]0-i felt that [my]0-i hands were coarse , and that [I]0-i was vulgar . [I]0-i never tried to see [him]2843-fellow again .

" [I]0-i stayed in [my]0-i situation four months after that , but [I]0-i was not happy . [I]0-i had no rest . [The people about [me]0-i]4802-the people about me pressed on [me]0-i , and made [me]0-i dissatisfied . [I]0-i could not forget [them]4802-the people about me . Even when [I]0-i did not see [them]4802-the people about me [they]4802-the people about me pressed on [me]0-i , and made [me]0-i miserable . [I]0-i did not love books ; [I]0-i wanted [people]249-people . When [I]0-i walked [home]302-home under the shady trees in [the street]1513-the street [I]0-i could not be happy , for when [I]0-i passed [the houses]4806-the houses [I]0-i heard music , and saw faces between the curtains . [I]0-i did not want any of them , but [I]0-i wanted[0-i]

some one for [mine]2845-mine , for [me]0-i . [I]0-i could not help it .

" Only one day something made [me]2846-me happy . [A nurse]4807-a nurse came to [the store]4732-the store with [a little girl belonging to one of [[our]4810-our clerks]4811-our clerks]4809-a little girl belonging to one of our clerks . While [the maid]222-the maid went into [the office]4813-the office to give a message to [[its]4809-a little girl belonging to one of our clerks father]4814-its father , [the little child]4815-the little child stood looking at [me]2846-me . Presently [she]4815-the little child came close to [me]2846-me and peeped up into [my]2846-me face . "[2846-me] " Nice curls , pretty curls , í [she]4815-the little child said ; "[2846-me] [I]0-i like curls.í " [She]4815-the little child felt [my]2857-the little girl hair all over , with [her]4815-the little child little hands . When [I]2857-the little girl put out [my]2857-the little girl arm [she]4815-the little child let [me]2857-the little girl take [her]4815-the little child and sit [her]4815-the little child on [my]2857-the little girl knee . [She]4815-the little child kissed [me]2857-the little girl with [her]4815-the little child soft mouth . [We]4816-we were happy till [the nurse - girl]4817-the nurse - girl came and shook [the little one]275-the little one , and asked [her]275-the little one if [she]275-the little one was not ashamed to sit on the knee of [that strange man]4819-that strange man . But [I]2857-the little girl do not think [[my]2857-the little girl little one]4820-my little one minded . [She]4815-the little child laughed at [me]2857-the little girl as [she]4815-the little child went out .[2857-the little girl]

" If [the world]252-the world was all [children]3428-children [I]54-em could like it ; but [men]3470-men and [women]1671-women draw [me]54-em so strangely , and then press [me]54-em away , till [I]54-em am in agony . [I]54-em was not meant to live among [people]249-people . Perhaps some day , when [I]54-em am grown older , [I]54-em will be able to go and live among [them]249-people and look at [them]249-people as [I]54-em look at the rocks and bushes , without letting [them]249-people disturb [me]54-em , and take [myself]54-em from [me]54-em ; but not now . So [I]54-em grew miserable ; a kind of fever seemed to eat [me]54-em ; [I]54-em could not rest , or read , or think ; so [I]54-em came here . [I]54-em knew [you]4826-you were not here , but it seemed as though [I]54-em should be nearer [you]4826-you ; and it is [you]4826-you [I]54-em want [you]4826-you that [the other people]4827-the other people suggest to [me]54-em , but can not give . "[54-em]

[He]2846-me had filled all the sheets [he]2846-me had taken , and now lifted down the last from the mantelpiece . [Em]54-em had dropped asleep , and lay slumbering peacefully on the skin before the fire . Out of doors the storm still raged ; but in a fitful manner , as though growing half weary of itself .

[He]2846-me bent over [his]2846-me paper again , with eager flushed cheek , and wrote on .

" It has been a delightful journey , this journey [home]302-home . [I]54-em have walked on foot . The evening before last , when it was just sunset , [I]54-em was a little footsore and thirsty , and went out of [the road]888-the road to look for water . [I]54-em went down into a deep little "[54-em] kloof.í Some trees ran along the bottom , and [I]0-i thought [I]0-i should find water there . The sun had quite set when [I]0-i got to the bottom of it . It was very still not a leaf was stirring anywhere . In the bed of [the mountain torrent]2847-the mountain torrent [I]0-i thought [I]0-i might find water . [I]0-i came to [the bank]4445-the bank , and leaped down into the dry bed . The floor on which [I]0-i stood was of fine white sand , and the banks rose on every side like the walls of [a room]2849-a room . Above there was a precipice of rocks , and a tiny stream of water oozed from them and fell slowly on to the flat stone below . Each drop [you]2850-you

could hear fall like a little silver bell . There was one among the trees on [the bank]4445-the bank that stood cut out against the white sky . All the other trees were silent ; but this one shook and trembled against the sky . Everything else was still ; but those leaves were quivering , quivering . [I]0-i stood on [the sand]287-the sand ; [I]0-i could not go away . When it was quite dark , and the stars had come , [I]0-i crept out . Does it seem strange to [you]2850-you that it should have made [me]0-i so happy ? It is because [I]0-i can not tell [you]2850-you how near [I]0-i felt to things that [we]2853-we can not see but [we]2853-we always feel . To - night has been a wild , stormy night . [I]0-i have been walking across [the plain]196-the plain for hours in the dark . [I]0-i have liked the wind , because [I]0-i have seemed forcing [my]0-i way through to [you]2850-you . [I]0-i knew [you]2850-you were not [here]3430-here , but [I]0-i would hear of [you]2850-you . When [I]0-i used to sit on the transport waggon half - sleeping , [I]0-i used to start awake because [your]2850-you hands were on [me]0-i . In

[[my]0-i lodgings]2856-my lodgings , night after night [I]0-i have blown the light out , and sat in the dark , that [I]0-i might see [your]2850-you face start out more distinctly . Sometimes it was [the little girl]2857-the little girl 's face who used to come to [me]0-i behind the " kopjeí when [I]2858-i minded the sheep , and sit by [me]2858-i in [her]2857-the little girl blue pinafore ; sometimes it was older . [I]2858-i love both . [I]2858-i am very helpless ; [I]2858-i shall never do anything ; but [you]2850-you will work , and [I]2858-i will take [your]2850-you work for [mine]2858-i . Sometimes such a sudden gladness seizes [me]2858-i when [I]2858-i remember that somewhere in [the world]252-the world [you]2850-you are living and working . [You]2850-you are [my]2858-i very own ; nothing else is [my]2858-i own so . When [I]2858-i have finished [I]2858-i am going to look at [[your]2850-you room]3530-your room door "[2858-i]

[He]2858-i wrote ; and the wind , which had spent its fury , moaned round and round [the house]206-the house , most like [a tired child weary with crying]2860-a tired child weary with crying .

[Em]54-em woke up , and sat before the fire , rubbing [her]54-em eyes , and listening , as it sobbed about the

gables , and wandered away over the long stone walls .

" How quiet it has grown now , "[2858-i] [she]54-em said , and sighed [herself]54-em , partly from weariness and partly from sympathy with the tired wind . [He]2858-i did not answer [her]54-em ; [he]2858-i was lost in [his]2858-i letter . [She]54-em rose slowly after a time , and rested [her]54-em hand on [his]2858-i shoulder . " [You]2858-i have many letters to write , "[54-em] [she]54-em said . " No , "[54-em] [he]2858-i answered ; " it is only one to [Lyndall]59-lyndall . "[54-em] [She]54-em turned away , and stood long before the fire looking into it . If [you]2858-i have a deadly fruit to give it will not grow sweeter by keeping . " [Waldo]60-waldo , [dear]3635-dear , "[2858-i] [she]54-em said , putting [her]54-em hand on [his]2858-i , " leave off writing . "[54-em] [He]2858-i threw back the dark hair from [his]2858-i forehead and looked at [her]54-em .

" It is no use writing any more , "[54-em] [she]54-em said . " Why not ? "[54-em] [he]2858-i asked . [She]54-em put [her]54-em hand over the papers [he]2858-i had written . " [Waldo]60-waldo , "[156-gregory] [she]54-em said , " [Lyndall]59-lyndall is dead . "[54-em]

CHAPTER XII . [GREGORY]156-gregory 'S WOMANHOOD .

SLOWLY over [the flat]616-the flat came [a cart]2862-a cart . On the back seat sat [Gregory]156-gregory , [his]156-gregory arms folded , [his]156-gregory hat drawn over [his]156-gregory eyes . [A Kaffir boy]2863-a kaffir boy sat on the front seat driving , and at [his]2863-a kaffir boy feet sat [Doss]70-doss , who , every now and again , lifted [his]70-doss nose and eyes above the level of the splash - board , to look at [the surrounding country]2864-the surrounding country ; and then , with an exceedingly knowing wink of [his]70-doss left eye , turned to [[his]70-doss companions]2865-his companions , thereby intimating that [he]70-doss clearly perceived [his]70-doss whereabouts . [No one]237-no one noticed [the cart]2314-the cart coming . [Waldo]60-waldo , who was at work at [[his]60-waldo carpenter]2868-his carpenter 's table in [the waggon - house]229-the waggon - house , saw nothing , till chancing to

look down [he]60-waldo perceived [Doss]70-doss standing before [him]60-waldo , the legs trembling , the little nose wrinkled , and a series of short , suffocating barks giving utterance to [his]70-doss joy at reunion .

[Em]54-em , whose eyes had ached with looking out across [the plain]196-the plain , was now at work in [a back - room]2871-a back - room , and knew nothing till , looking up , [she]54-em saw [Gregory]156-gregory , with [his]156-gregory straw hat and blue eyes , standing in the door - way . [He]156-gregory greeted [her]54-em quietly , hung [his]156-gregory hat up in its old place behind the door , and for any change in [his]156-gregory manner or appearance [he]156-gregory might have been gone only the day before to fetch letters from [the town]612-the town . Only [his]156-gregory beard was gone , and [his]156-gregory face was grown thinner . [He]156-gregory took off [his]156-gregory leather gaiters , said the afternoon was hot and [the roads]2873-the roads dusty , and asked for some tea . [They]2874-they talked of wool , cattle , and sheep , and [Em]54-em gave [him]156-gregory the pile of letters that had come for [him]156-gregory during that seven months ' absence , but of the

thing that lay at [their]2874-they hearts neither said anything . Then [he]156-gregory went out to look at [the kraals]3975-the kraals , and at supper [Em]54-em gave [him]156-gregory hot cakes and coffee . [They]2874-they talked about [the servants]1986-the servants , and then ate [their]2874-they meal in quiet . When it was ended [Gregory]156-gregory went into [the front - room]2239-the front - room , and lay in the dark on the sofa .

" Do [you]156-gregory not want a light ? "[156-gregory] [Em]54-em asked , venturing to look in . " No , "[54-em] [he]156-gregory answered ; then presently called to [her]54-em , " Come and sit here ; [I]156-gregory want to talk to [you]54-em . "[156-gregory] [She]54-em came and sat on a footstool near [him]156-gregory . " Do [you]54-em wish to hear anything ? "[156-gregory] [he]156-gregory asked . [She]54-em whispered , " Yes , if it does not hurt [you]156-gregory . "[156-gregory] " What difference does it make to [me]156-gregory ? "[156-gregory] [he]156-gregory said . " If [I]156-gregory talk or am silent , is there any change ? "[156-gregory]

Yet [he]156-gregory lay quiet for a long time . The light through the open door showed [him]156-gregory to [her]54-em ,

where [he]156-gregory lay , with [his]156-gregory arm thrown across [his]156-gregory eyes . At last [he]156-gregory spoke . Perhaps it was a relief to [him]156-gregory to speak .

To [Bloemfontein]47-bloemfontein in [the Free State]3655-the free state , to which through [an agent [he]156-gregory had traced [them]2880-they]2879-an agent he had traced them , [Gregory]156-gregory had gone . At [the hotel where [Lyndall]59-lyndall and [[her]59-lyndall stranger]2882-her stranger had stayed]2881-the hotel where lyndall and her stranger had stayed [he]156-gregory put up ; [he]156-gregory was shown [the very room in which [they]2880-they had slept]2883-the very room in which they had slept . [The coloured boy who had driven [them]2880-they to [the next town]4728-the next town]2884-the coloured boy who had driven them to the next town told [him]156-gregory in [which house]2886-which house [they]2880-they had boarded , and [Gregory]156-gregory went on . In [that town]2887-that town [he]156-gregory found [they]2880-they had left [the cart]2314-the cart , and bought a spider and four greys , and [Gregory]156-gregory 's heart rejoiced . Now indeed it would be easy to trace [their]2880-they course . And [he]156-gregory turned [his]156-gregory steps northward .

At [[the farm]260-the farm - houses where [he]156-gregory stopped the " ooms "[345-the girl] and " tantes "]4833-the farm - houses where he stopped the " ooms " and " tantes "[345-the girl] remembered clearly the spider with its four grey horses . At one place [the Boer - wife]2085-the boer - wife told how [the Englishman]3974-the englishman had bought milk , and asked the way to [the next

farm]3819-the next farm . At [the next farm]3819-the next farm [the Englishman]3974-the englishman had bought a bunch of flowers , and given half - a - crown for them to [the little girl]2857-the little girl . It was quite true ; [the Boer - mother]2896-the boer - mother made [her]2896-the boer - mother get it out of the box and show it . At the next place [they]2880-they had slept . Here [they]2880-they told [him]156-gregory that the great bull - dog , who hated [all strangers]2897-all strangers , had walked in in the evening and laid its head in [the lady]2898-the lady 's lap . So at every place [he]156-gregory heard something , and traced [them]2880-they step by step .

At [one desolate farm]2899-one desolate farm [the Boer]2900-the boer had a good deal to tell . [The lady]2898-the lady had said [she]2898-the lady liked a waggon that stood before the door . Without asking the price [the Englishman]112-englishman had offered a hundred and fifty pounds for the old thing , and bought oxen worth ten pounds for sixteen . [The Dutchman]2902-the dutchman chuckled , for [he]156-gregory had the " Salt - reim 's "[2898-the lady] money in the box under [his]156-gregory bed . [Gregory]156-gregory laughed too , in silence ; [he]156-gregory could not lose sight of [them]2880-they now , so slowly [they]2880-they would have to move with that

cumbrous ox - waggon . Yet , when that evening came , and [he]156-gregory reached [a little wayside inn]2903-a little wayside inn , [no one]237-no one could tell [him]156-gregory anything of [the travellers]2905-the travellers .

[The master]4633-the master , a surly creature , half stupid with Boer - brandy , sat on the bench before the door smoking . [Gregory]156-gregory sat beside [him]4633-the master , questioning , but [he]156-gregory smoked on . [He]156-gregory remembered nothing of [such strangers]2907-such strangers . How should [he]156-gregory know who had been [there]317-there months and months before ? [He]156-gregory smoked on . [Gregory]156-gregory , very weary , tried to wake [his]156-gregory memory , said that [the lady [he]156-gregory was seeking for]2909-the lady he was seeking for was very beautiful , had a little mouth , and tiny , very tiny , feet . [The man]372-the man only smoked on as sullenly as at first . What were little , very little mouths and feet to [him]372-the man . But [[his]156-gregory daughter]1933-his daughter leaned out in the window above . [She]1933-his daughter was dirty and lazy , and liked to loll there when [travellers]3628-travellers came , to hear [the men]1452-the men talk , but [she]1933-his daughter had a soft heart . Presently a hand came out of the window , and a pair of velvet slippers touched [his]156-gregory shoulder , tiny slippers

with black flowers . [He]156-gregory pulled them out of [her]1933-his daughter hand . Only [one woman]2914-one woman 's feet had worn them , [he]156-gregory knew that .

" Left [here]3430-here last summer by [a lady]1357-a lady , "[4836-the good old " ooms " and " tantes "] said [the girl]345-the girl ; " might be the one [you]156-gregory are looking for . Never saw any feet so small . "[4836-the good old " ooms " and " tantes "] [Gregory]156-gregory rose and questioned [her]345-the girl . [They]2916-they might have come in a waggon and spider , [she]345-the girl could not tell . But [the gentleman]2917-the gentleman was very handsome , tall , lovely figure , blue eyes , wore gloves always when [he]2917-the gentleman went out . [An English officer]2918-an english officer , perhaps ; [no Africander]2919-no africander , certainly . [Gregory]156-gregory stopped [her]345-the girl .

[The lady]2898-the lady ? Well , [she]2898-the lady was pretty , rather , [the girl]345-the girl said ; very cold , dull hair , silent . [They]2916-they stayed for , it might be , five days ; slept in the wing over against the " stoep "[441-a gentleman] ; quarrelled sometimes , [she]345-the girl thought [the lady]2898-the lady . [She]2898-the lady had seen everything when [she]2898-the lady went in to wait . One day [the gentleman]2917-the gentleman touched [her]345-the girl hair ; [she]345-the girl drew back

from [him]2917-the gentleman as though [his]2917-the gentleman fingers poisoned [her]345-the girl . Went to the other end of [the room]215-the room if [he]2917-the gentleman came to sit near [her]345-the girl . Walked out alone . [Cold wife]2925-cold wife for [such a handsome husband]2926-such a handsome husband , [the girl]345-the girl thought ; [she]345-the girl evidently pitied [him]2917-the gentleman . [They]2916-they went away early one morning , how , or in which way , [the girl]345-the girl could not tell .

[Gregory]156-gregory inquired of [the servants]1986-the servants , but nothing more was to be learnt ; so the next morning [he]156-gregory saddled [his]156-gregory horse and went on . At [the farms]2930-the farms [he]156-gregory came to [the good old " ooms "[156-gregory] and " tantes "]4836-the good old " ooms " and " tantes "[156-gregory] asked [him]156-gregory to have coffee , and [the little shoeless children]2931-the little shoeless children peeped out at [the stranger]418-the stranger from behind ovens and [gables]2933-gables ; but [no one]237-no one had seen what [he]156-gregory asked for . This way and that [he]156-gregory rode to pick up the thread [he]156-gregory had dropped , but the spider and the waggon , [the little lady]2935-the little lady and [the handsome gentleman]2936-the handsome gentleman , [no one]237-no one had seen . In [the towns]2938-the towns [he]156-gregory fared yet worse .

Once indeed hope came to [him]156-gregory . On the

" stoep "[540-a woman] of [an hotel at which [he]156-gregory stayed the night in [a certain little village]2940-a certain little village]2939-an hotel at which he stayed the night in a certain little village , there walked [a gentleman]441-a gentleman , grave and kindly - looking . It was not hard to open conversation with [him]156-gregory about the weather , and then ; Had [he]156-gregory ever seen [such and such people]2942-such and such people , [a gentleman]441-a gentleman and [a lady]1357-a lady , a spider and waggon , arrive at [that place]1542-that place . [The kindly gentleman]2946-the kindly gentleman shook [his]2946-the kindly gentleman head . What was [the lady]2898-the lady like , [he]2946-the kindly gentleman inquired ?

[Gregory]156-gregory painted . Hair like silken floss , small mouth , underlip very full and pink , upper lip pink but very thin and curled ; there were four white spots on the nail of the forefinger , the eyebrows very straight . " Yes ; and a rose - bud tinge in the cheeks ; hands like lilies , and perfectly seraphic smile . "[540-a woman] " That is [she]2898-the lady ! that is [she]2898-the lady ! "[540-a woman] cried [Gregory]156-gregory .

Who else could it be ? [He]156-gregory asked where [she]2898-the lady

had gone to . [The gentleman]2917-the gentleman most thoughtfully stroked [his]2917-the gentleman beard . [He]2917-the gentleman would try to remember . Were not [her]2898-the lady ears . Here such a violent fit of coughing seized [him]2917-the gentleman that [he]2917-the gentleman ran away into [the house]206-the house . [An ill - fed clerk]2950-an ill - fed clerk and [a dirty barman standing in the door - way]2951-a dirty barman standing in the door - way laughed aloud . [Gregory]156-gregory wondered if [they]2952-they could be laughing at [the gentleman]2917-the gentleman 's cough , and then [he]156-gregory heard [some one]3445-some one laughing in [the room into which [the gentleman]2917-the gentleman had gone]2955-the room into which the gentleman had gone . [He]156-gregory must follow [him]3445-some one and try to learn more ; but [he]156-gregory soon found that there was nothing more to be learnt [there]317-there . [Poor Gregory]156-gregory !

Backward and forwards , backward and forwards , from [the dirty little hotel]2958-the dirty little hotel where [he]2917-the gentleman had dropped the thread , to [this farm]3442-this farm and to that , rode [Gregory]156-gregory , till [his]156-gregory heart was sick and tired . That from that spot the waggon might have gone its own way and the spider another was an idea that did not occur to [him]156-gregory . At last [he]156-gregory saw

it was no use lingering in [that neighbourhood]2960-that neighbourhood , and pressed on .

One day , coming to [a little town]2961-a little town , [his]156-gregory horses knocked up , and [he]156-gregory resolved to rest [them]2962-them [there]317-there . [[The little hotel]2964-the little hotel of [the town]612-the town]2965-the little hotel of the town was [a bright and sunny place]2967-a bright and sunny place , like the jovial face of [the clean little woman who kept it]2968-the clean little woman who kept it , and who trotted about talking always talking to [the customers in [the tap - room]2970-the tap - room]2969-the customers in the tap - room , and to [the maids in [the kitchen]798-the kitchen]2971-the maids in the kitchen , and to [the passers - by]2973-the passers - by when [she]2968-the clean little woman who kept it could hail [them]2973-the passers - by from the windows ; talking , as [good - natured women with large mouths and small noses]2974-good - natured women with large mouths and small noses always do , in season and out .

There was [a little front parlour in [the hotel]2976-the hotel]2975-a little front parlour in the hotel , kept for [strangers who wanted to be alone]2977-strangers who wanted to be alone . [Gregory]156-gregory sat there to eat [his]156-gregory breakfast , and [the landlady]2978-the landlady dusted [the room]215-the room and talked of the great finds at [the Diamond Fields]2771-the diamond fields , and the badness of [maid - servants]2981-maid - servants , and the shameful conduct of [the Dutch parson in [that town]2887-that town]2982-the dutch parson in that town to the English

in- [inhabitants

habitants]2984-inhabitants habitants . [Gregory]156-gregory ate [his]156-gregory breakfast and listened to nothing . [He]156-gregory had asked [his]156-gregory one question , and had had [his]156-gregory answer ; now [she]2978-the landlady might talk on .

Presently a door in the corner opened and [a woman]540-a woman came out a Mozambiquer , with a red handkerchief twisted round [her]540-a woman head . [She]540-a woman carried in [her]540-a woman hand a tray , with a slice of toast crumbled fine , and a half - filled cup of coffee , and an egg broken open , but not eaten . [Her]540-a woman ebony face grinned complacently as [she]540-a woman shut the door softly and said , " Good morning . "[2987-the mozambiquer] [The landlady]2978-the landlady began to talk to [her]540-a woman . " [You]540-a woman are not going to leave [her]540-a woman really , [Ayah]184-ayah , are [you]540-a woman ? "[2978-the landlady] [she]540-a woman said . " [The maids]4499-the maids say so ; but [I]2978-the landlady 'm sure [you]540-a woman would n't do such a thing . "[2978-the landlady] [The Mozambiquer]2987-the mozambiquer grinned . " [Husband]4838-husband says [I]2978-the landlady must go [home]302-home .
